这是经典的货币和信贷循环的一部分，从有历史记录以来就一直在发生，我将在第三章更完整地解释。简而言之，信贷崩溃的发生是因为有太多的债务。通常情况下，中央政府必须花很多它没有的钱，让债务人更容易偿还债务，中央银行总是要印钞票，自由地提供信贷，就像他们在应对由 COVID 大流行和大量债务推动的经济暴跌时所做的那样。1930 年代的债务萧条是咆哮的 20 年代繁荣的自然延伸，它成为一个由债务资助的泡沫，在 1929 年破裂。这产生了一场大萧条，导致中央政府的大笔支出和借贷，由中央银行的大笔货币和信贷创造资助。

Back then, the popping of the bubble and the resulting economic bust were the biggest influences on the 1930–45 period’s internal and external fights for wealth and power. Then, like now and like in most other cases, there were large wealth gaps and conflict, which when heightened by debt/economic collapses, led to revolutionary changes in social and economic programs and big wealth transfers that were manifest in different systems in different countries. Clashes and wars developed over which of these systems—e.g., capitalism or communism, democracy or autocracy—were best. There are always arguments or fights between those who want to make big redistributions of wealth and those who don’t. In the 1930s, Mother Nature also gave the US a painful drought.

当年，泡沫的破灭和随之而来的经济萧条是 1930-45 年期间财富和权力的内部和外部斗争的最大影响因素。当时，就像现在和其他大多数情况一样，存在着巨大的财富差距和冲突，当债务/经济崩溃加剧时，导致了社会和经济项目的革命性变化，以及在不同国家不同系统中表现出来的巨大财富转移。在这些制度中，哪种制度 —— 例如，资本主义或共产主义，民主或专制 —— 是最好的，冲突和战争随之发展。在那些想要进行大规模财富再分配的人和那些不想要的人之间，总是有争论或争斗。在 1930 年代，大自然也给了美国一场痛苦的干旱。

Looking over the whole of the cases I examined, past economic and market declines lasted about three years, give or take a few years, depending on how long it took to do the debt restructuring and/or debt monetization process. The quicker the printing of money to fill the debt holes, the quicker the closing of the deflationary depression and the sooner the worrying about the value of money began. In the 1930s US case, the stock market and the economy bottomed the day that the newly elected president, Franklin D. Roosevelt, announced that he would default on the government’s promise to let people turn in their money for gold, and that the government would create enough money and credit so that people could get their money out of the banks and others could get money and credit to buy things and invest. That took three-and-a-half years from the initial stock market crash in October 1929.6

纵观我所研究的全部案例，过去的经济和市场下跌大约持续了三年，或多或少取决于进行债务重组和/或债务货币化过程需要多长时间。印刷钞票填补债务漏洞的速度越快，通货紧缩萧条的结束就越快，对货币价值的担忧也就越早开始。在 20 世纪 30 年代的美国案例中，股市和经济在新当选的总统富兰克林-D-罗斯福宣布他将默认政府的承诺，让人们把钱交出来换成黄金，政府将创造足够的货币和信贷，以便人们可以把钱从银行里拿出来，其他人可以获得货币和信贷来购买东西和投资。从 1929 年 10 月最初的股票市场崩溃开始，这花了三年半时间。6

Still there was fighting over wealth and power within and between countries. The emerging powers of Germany and Japan challenged the existing leading world powers of Great Britain, France, and eventually the US (which was dragged into World War II). The war period raised the economic output of things that were used in the war, but it would be a misnomer to call the war years a “productive” period—even though when measured in output per person, it was—because there was so much destruction. At the end of the war, global GDP per capita had fallen by about 12 percent, much of which was driven by declines in the economies of countries that lost the war. The stress test that these years represented wiped out a lot, made clear who the winners and losers were, and led to a new beginning and a new world order in 1945. Classically that was followed by a lengthy period of peace and prosperity that became overextended so that all countries are now, 75 years later, being stress tested again.

国家内部和国家之间仍然存在着对财富和权力的争夺。新兴的德国和日本向现有的英国、法国和最终的美国（被拖入第二次世界大战）等世界大国发起挑战。战争时期提高了在战争中使用的东西的经济产出，但把战争年代称为 “生产性” 时期是一个错误的说法 —— 尽管以人均产出衡量，它是 —— 因为有这么多破坏。在战争结束时，全球人均 GDP 下降了约 12%，其中大部分是由战争失败国家的经济下降所造成的。这些年所代表的压力测试消灭了很多，明确了谁是赢家和输家，并在 1945 年导致了一个新的开始和一个新的世界秩序。通常情况下，这之后是一个漫长的和平与繁荣时期，变得过度扩张，以至于 75 年后的今天，所有国家都在再次接受压力测试。

Most cycles in history happen for basically the same reasons. For example, the 1907–19 period began with the Panic of 1907 in the US, which, like the 1929–32 money and credit crisis following the Roaring ’20s, was the result of a boom period (the Gilded Age in the US, which was the same time as the Belle Époque in continental Europe and the Victorian Era in Great Britain) becoming a debt-financed bubble that led to economic and market declines. These declines also happened when there were large wealth gaps that led to big wealth redistributions and contributed to a world war. The wealth redistributions, like those in the 1930–45 period, came about through large increases in taxes and government spending, big deficits, and big changes in monetary policies that monetized the deficits. Then the Spanish flu intensified the stress test and the resulting restructuring process. This stress test and global economic and geopolitical restructuring led to a new world order in 1919, which was expressed in the Treaty of Versailles. That ushered in the 1920s debt-financed boom, which led to the 1930–45 period and the same things happening again.

历史上大多数周期发生的原因基本相同。例如，1907-19 年期间以美国的 1907 年恐慌开始，就像咆哮的 20 年代之后的 1929-32 年货币和信贷危机一样，是繁荣时期（美国的镀金时代，与欧洲大陆的美好时代和英国的维多利亚时代是同一时期）成为债务融资泡沫的结果，导致了经济和市场衰退。这些衰落也发生在存在巨大的财富差距的时候，导致了大的财富再分配，并促成了一场世界大战。财富再分配，就像 1930-45 年期间的财富再分配一样，是通过大量增加税收和政府开支、大额赤字和货币政策的巨大变化使赤字货币化而产生的。然后，西班牙流感加剧了压力测试和由此产生的结构调整过程。这种压力测试以及全球经济和地缘政治的重组导致了 1919 年的世界新秩序，这在《凡尔赛条约》中得到了体现。这迎来了 20 世纪 20 年代由债务资助的繁荣，这导致了 1930-45 年期间，同样的事情再次发生。

These periods of destruction/reconstruction devastated the weak, made clear who the powerful were, and established revolutionary new approaches to doing things (i.e., new orders) that set the stage for periods of prosperity that eventually became overextended as debt bubbles with large wealth gaps and led to debt busts that produced new stress tests and destruction/reconstruction periods (i.e., wars), which led to new orders and eventually the strong again gaining relative to the weak, and so on.

这些破坏/重建时期摧毁了弱者，明确了谁是强者，并建立了革命性的新的做事方法（即新秩序），为繁荣时期奠定了基础，这些繁荣时期最终成为过度扩张的债务泡沫，财富差距巨大，并导致债务萧条，产生新的压力测试和破坏/重建时期（即战争），这导致了新秩序，最终强者再次获得相对于弱者的地位，等等。

What are these destruction/reconstruction periods like for the people who experience them? Since you likely haven’t been through one of these and the stories about them are very scary, the prospect of being in one is worrisome to most people. It is true that these destruction/ reconstruction periods have produced tremendous human suffering both financially and, more importantly, in lost or damaged human lives. While the consequences are worse for some people, virtually no one escapes the damage. Still, without minimizing them, history has shown us that typically the majority of people stay employed in depressions, are unharmed in shooting wars, and survive natural disasters.

这些破坏/重建时期对经历过的人来说是什么样的？因为你可能没有经历过这些，而且关于它们的故事非常可怕，所以对大多数人来说，身处其中的前景是令人担忧的。诚然，这些破坏/重建时期在经济上产生了巨大的人类痛苦，更重要的是，在失去或损坏人的生命方面。虽然这些后果对一些人来说更糟糕，但几乎没有人能够逃脱损害。不过，在不贬低它们的情况下，历史告诉我们，通常大多数人在经济萧条中保持就业，在枪战中安然无恙，在自然灾害中幸存下来。

Some people who struggled through them have even described these very difficult times as bringing about important, good things like drawing people closer together, building strength of character, learning to appreciate the basics, etc. For example, Tom Brokaw called the people who went through the 1930–45 period “the Greatest Generation” because of the strength of character it gave them. My parents and aunts and uncles who went through the Great Depression and World War II, as well as others of their era whom I’ve spoken to in other countries who went through their own versions of this destruction period, saw it that way too. Keep in mind that economic destruction periods and war periods typically don’t last very long—roughly two or three years. And the lengths and severities of natural disasters (like droughts, floods, and epidemics) vary, though they typically lessen in painfulness as adaptations are made. One rarely gets all three of these types of big crises—economic, revolution/war, and natural disaster—at the same time.

一些经历过这些时期的人甚至将这些非常困难的时期描述为带来了重要的、好的东西，如拉近人与人之间的距离，培养性格的力量，学会欣赏基本的东西，等等。例如，汤姆·布罗考（Tom Brokaw）称经历过 1930-45 年的人是 “最伟大的一代”，因为这给他们带来了性格上的力量。我的父母和经历过大萧条和二战的叔叔阿姨们，以及我在其他国家与之交谈过的经历过这种破坏期的同龄人，也是这样看待的。请记住，经济破坏期和战争期通常不会持续很久 —— 大约两三年。自然灾害（如干旱、洪水和流行病）的长度和严重程度也各不相同，尽管它们通常会随着适应的进行而减轻痛苦。人们很少在同一时间得到这三种类型的大危机 —— 经济、革命/战争和自然灾害。

My point is that while these revolution/war periods typically lead to a lot of human suffering, we should never, especially in the worst of times, lose sight of the fact that one can navigate them well—and that humanity’s power to adapt and quickly get to new and higher levels of well-being is much greater than all the bad stuff that can be thrown at us. For that reason, I believe that it is smart to trust and invest in humanity’s adaptability and inventiveness. So, while I am pretty sure that in the coming years both you and I and the world order will experience big challenges and changes, I believe that humanity will become smarter and stronger in very practical ways that will lead us to overcome these challenging times and go on to new and higher levels of prosperity.

我的观点是，虽然这些革命/战争时期通常会导致大量的人类痛苦，但我们永远不应该，尤其是在最糟糕的时期，忽视一个事实，即人们可以很好地驾驭它们，而且人类适应和迅速获得新的和更高水平的福祉的能力，比所有可以扔给我们的坏东西大得多。出于这个原因，我认为相信并投资于人类的适应性和创造性是明智的。因此，虽然我非常肯定，在未来几年里，你和我以及世界秩序都将经历巨大的挑战和变化，但我相信，人类将以非常实际的方式变得更加聪明和强大，这将引导我们克服这些挑战，走向新的和更高水平的繁荣。

Now let’s look at the cycles of rises and declines in the wealth and power of the major countries over the last 500 years.

现在让我们来看看过去 500 年里主要国家的财富和权力的上升和下降周期。

PAST BIG CYCLE SHIFTS IN WEALTH AND POWER

过去财富和权力的大周期转变

The chart of rising productivity shown earlier was for the whole world (to the best of our ability to measure it). It doesn’t show the shifts in wealth and power that occurred between countries. To understand how those happen, let’s start with the big-picture basics. Throughout recorded history various forms of groups of people (e.g., tribes, kingdoms, countries, etc.) have gained wealth and power by building it themselves, taking it from others, or finding it in the ground. When they gathered more wealth and power than any other group, they became the world’s leading power, which allowed them to determine the world order. When they lost that wealth and power, which they all did, the world order—and all aspects of life—changed in profound ways.

前面显示的生产力上升的图表是针对整个世界的（就我们测量的能力而言）。它没有显示国家之间发生的财富和权力的转移。为了理解这些是如何发生的，让我们从大局观的基础知识开始。纵观有记载的历史，各种形式的人群（如部落、王国、国家等）通过自己建造、从他人手中夺取或在地下找到财富和权力。当他们聚集了比其他任何群体更多的财富和权力时，他们就成为世界上的主导力量，这使他们能够决定世界秩序。当他们失去这种财富和权力时 —— 他们都是如此 —— 世界秩序和生活的各个方面都发生了深刻的变化。

The next chart shows the relative wealth and power of the 11 leading empires over the last 500 years.

下图显示了过去 500 年中 11 个主要帝国的相对财富和权力。

Each one of these indices 7 of wealth and power is a composite of eight different determinants that I will explain shortly. Though these indices aren’t perfect because all data through time isn’t perfect, they do an excellent job of painting the big picture. As you can see, nearly all of these empires saw periods of ascendancy followed by periods of decline.

这些指数中的每一项 7 财富和权力的每一个指数都是由八个不同的决定因素组成的，我很快就会解释。尽管这些指数并不完美，因为所有的时间数据都不完美，但它们在描绘大局方面做得很好。正如你所看到的，几乎所有这些帝国都经历了上升期，然后是衰退期。

Take a moment to study the thicker lines on the chart, which represent the four most important empires: the Dutch, British, American, and Chinese. These empires held the last three reserve currencies—the US dollar now, the British pound before it, and the Dutch guilder before that. China is included because it has risen to be the second most powerful empire/country and because it was so consistently powerful in most years prior to around 1850. To very briefly summarize the story this chart shows:

花点时间研究一下图表上较粗的线条，它们代表了四个最重要的帝国：荷兰、英国、美国和中国。这些帝国持有最后三种储备货币 —— 现在的美元，之前的英镑，以及之前的荷兰盾。中国之所以被包括在内，是因为它已经上升为第二大最强大的帝国/国家，而且在 1850 年左右之前的大多数年份，它都是如此持续强大。非常简单地总结一下这个图表所显示的故事。

  • China was dominant for centuries (consistently out-competing Europe economically and otherwise), though it entered a steep decline starting in the 1800s.
  • 几个世纪以来，中国一直处于主导地位（在经济上和其他方面一直超过欧洲），尽管从 19 世纪开始，中国进入了一个急剧的衰退期。
  • The Netherlands, a relatively small country, became the world’s reserve currency empire in the 1600s.
  • 荷兰，一个相对较小的国家，在 16 世纪成为世界的储备货币帝国。
  • The UK followed a very similar path, peaking in the 1800s.
  • 英国走了一条非常相似的道路，在 19 世纪达到顶峰。
  • Finally, the US rose to become the world’s superpower over the last 150 years, though particularly during and after World War II.
  • 最后，美国在过去 150 年里崛起为世界超级大国，尽管特别是在二战期间和之后。
  • The US is now in relative decline while China is rising again.
  • 美国现在正处于相对衰落状态，而中国正在重新崛起。

Now let’s look at the same chart that extends the data all the way back to the year 600. I focused on the first chart (which covers just the last 500 years) rather than the second (which covers the last 1,400 years) because it highlights the empires I studied most intently and is simpler—though with 11 countries, 12 major wars, and over 500 years, it can hardly be called simple. Still, the second is more extensive and worth glancing at. I left out the shading of the war periods to lessen the complexity. As shown, in the pre-1500 period, China was almost always the most powerful, though the Middle Eastern caliphates, the French, the Mongols, the Spanish, and the Ottomans were also in the picture.

现在让我们看一下将数据一直延伸到 600 年的同一张图表。我专注于第一张图表（仅涵盖过去 500 年），而不是第二张（涵盖过去 1400 年），因为它突出了我最深入研究的帝国，而且更简单 —— 尽管有 11 个国家、12 场重大战争和超过 500 年的历史，它很难被称为简单。不过，第二张图的内容更广泛，值得一看。我省去了战争时期的阴影，以减少其复杂性。如图所示，在 1500 年以前的时期，中国几乎总是最强大的，尽管中东哈里发、法国、蒙古、西班牙和奥斯曼也在其中。

An important thing to remember: while the leading powers covered in this study were the richest and most powerful, they weren’t necessarily the best-off countries for two reasons. First, while wealth and power are what most people want and will fight over most, some people and their countries don’t think that these things are the most important and wouldn’t think of fighting over them. Some believe that having peace and savoring life are more important than having a lot of wealth and power and wouldn’t consider fighting hard enough to gain enough of the wealth and power to make it into this study, though some of them enjoyed greater amounts of peace than those who fought for wealth and power. (By the way, I think there is a lot to be said for putting peace and savoring life ahead of gaining wealth and power—interestingly, there was little correlation between the wealth and power of a nation and the happiness of its people, which is a subject for another time.) Second, this group of countries excludes what I will call the “boutique countries” (like Switzerland and Singapore) that score very high in wealth and living standards but aren’t large enough to become one of the biggest empires.

需要记住的一件事是：虽然这项研究中涉及的主要大国是最富有和最强大的，但它们不一定是最富裕的国家，原因有二。首先，虽然财富和权力是大多数人想要的，也是最会争夺的，但有些人和他们的国家并不认为这些东西是最重要的，也不会想到要为它们而战。有些人认为，拥有和平和品味生活比拥有大量财富和权力更重要，不会考虑为获得足够的财富和权力而努力奋斗，以进入这项研究，尽管他们中的一些人比那些为财富和权力而奋斗的人享有更多的和平。（顺便说一下，我认为把和平和品味生活放在获得财富和权力之前有很多说法 —— 有趣的是，一个国家的财富和权力与其人民的幸福之间几乎没有关联，这是另一个话题。）第二，这组国家不包括我所说的 “精品国家”（如瑞士和新加坡），它们在财富和生活水平方面得分很高，但还没有大到可以成为最大的帝国之一。

EIGHT DETERMINANTS OF WEALTH AND POWER

财富和权力的八个决定因素

The single measure of wealth and power that I showed you for each country in the prior charts is a roughly equal average of 18 measures of strength. While we will explore the full list of determinants later, let’s begin by focusing on the key eight shown in the next chart: 1) education, 2) competitiveness, 3) innovation and technology, 4) economic output, 5) share of world trade, 6) military strength, 7) financial center strength, and 8) reserve currency status.

我在前面的图表中向你展示的每个国家的财富和权力的单一衡量标准，是 18 种力量衡量标准的大致相等的平均值。虽然我们稍后会探讨全部的决定因素，但让我们首先关注下一张图表中显示的关键的八个因素。1）教育，2）竞争力，3）创新和技术，4）经济产出，5）世界贸易份额，6）军事力量，7）金融中心实力，以及 8）储备货币地位。

This chart shows the average of each of these measures of strength across all the empires I studied, with most of the weight on the most recent three reserve countries (i.e., the US, the UK, and the Netherlands). 8

这张图显示了我研究的所有帝国的这些实力衡量标准的平均值，其中大部分的权重在最近的三个储备国（即美国、英国和荷兰）上。 8

The lines in the chart do a pretty good job of telling the story of why and how the rises and declines took place. You can see how rising education leads to increased innovation and technology, which leads to an increased share of world trade and military strength, stronger economic output, the building of the world’s leading financial center, and, with a lag, the establishment of the currency as a reserve currency. And you can see how for an extended period most of these factors stayed strong together and then declined in a similar order. The common reserve currency, just like the world’s common language, tends to stick around after an empire has begun its decline because the habit of usage lasts longer than the strengths that made it so commonly used.

图表中的线条很好地讲述了为什么以及如何发生上升和下降的故事。你可以看到教育水平的提高如何导致创新和技术的增加，从而导致在世界贸易和军事力量中的份额增加，更强大的经济产出，建立世界领先的金融中心，以及滞后的货币作为储备货币的建立。而且你可以看到，在一个较长的时期内，这些因素中的大多数是一起保持强劲，然后以类似的顺序下降的。共同的储备货币，就像世界上共同的语言一样，往往在一个帝国开始衰落之后还能坚持下去，因为使用的习惯比使其普遍使用的力量更持久。

I call this cyclical, interrelated move up and down the Big Cycle. Using these determinants and some additional dynamics, I will next describe the Big Cycle in more detail. But before I start, it’s worth reiterating that all of these measures of strength rose and declined over the arc of the empire. That’s because these strengths and weaknesses are mutually reinforcing —i.e., strengths and weaknesses in education, competitiveness, economic output, share of world trade, etc., contribute to the others being strong or weak, for logical reasons.

我把这种周期性的、相互关联的上下移动称为大周期。利用这些决定因素和一些额外的动力，我接下来将更详细地描述大周期。但在我开始之前，值得重申的是，所有这些力量的衡量标准在帝国的弧线上都有上升和下降。这是因为这些优势和劣势是相互促进的 —— 即教育、竞争力、经济产出、世界贸易份额等方面的优势和劣势，有助于其他方面的强势或弱势，这是合乎逻辑的。

THE ARCHETYPICAL BIG CYCLE

典型的大循环

Broadly speaking, we can look at these rises and declines as happening in three phases:

概括地说，我们可以把这些上升和下降看成是分三个阶段发生的。

The Rise:

崛起。

The rise is the prosperous period of building that comes after a new order. It is when the country is fundamentally strong because there are a) relatively low levels of indebtedness, b) relatively small wealth, values, and political gaps between people, c) people working effectively together to produce prosperity, d) good education and infrastructure, e) strong and capable leadership, and f) a peaceful world order that is guided by one or more dominant world powers, which leads to…

崛起是指新秩序之后的建设繁荣期。这时的国家从根本上说是强大的，因为有：a）相对较低的负债水平，b）人们之间相对较小的财富、价值观和政治差距，c）人们有效地合作产生繁荣，d）良好的教育和基础设施，e）强大和有能力的领导，以及 f）由一个或多个主导的世界大国指导的和平世界秩序，这导致……

The Top:

顶端。

This period is characterized by excesses in the form of a) high levels of indebtedness, b) large wealth, values, and political gaps, c) declining education and infrastructure, d) conflicts between different classes of people within countries, and e) struggles between countries as overextended empires are challenged by emerging rivals, which leads to…

这一时期的特点是：a）高额负债，b）巨大的财富、价值观和政治差距，c）教育和基础设施的下降，d）国家内部不同阶层的冲突，e）国家之间的斗争，因为过度扩张的帝国受到新兴对手的挑战，这导致了……

The Decline:

衰落。

This is the painful period of fighting and restructuring that leads to great conflicts and great changes and the establishment of new internal and external orders. It sets the stage for the next new order and a new period of prosperous building.

这是一个痛苦的战斗和重组时期，它导致了巨大的冲突和巨大的变化，建立了新的内部和外部秩序。它为下一个新秩序和新时期的繁荣建设创造了条件。

Let’s look at each of these in more detail.

让我们更详细地看一下每一个问题。

THE RISE

崛起

The rise phase begins when there is…

上升阶段开始时，出现了……

  • … strong enough and capable enough leadership to gain power and design an excellent system to increase the country’s wealth and power. Looking at the historically great empires, this system typically involves…
  • …… 足够强大和有能力的领导层来获得权力，并设计一个优秀的系统来增加国家的财富和权力。纵观历史上的大帝国，这种制度通常涉及……
  • … strong education, which is not just teaching knowledge and skills; it also includes teaching…
  • …… 强化教育，这不仅仅是教授知识和技能，还包括教授……
  • … strong character, civility, and work ethic development. These are typically taught in families, schools, and/or religious institutions. If done well, this provides a healthy respect for rules and laws and order within society, leads to low corruption rates, and is effective in encouraging people to work together to improve productivity. The better the country does this, the more there will be a shift from producing basic products to…
  • …… 坚强的性格、文明和工作道德的发展。这些通常是在家庭、学校和/或宗教机构中教授的。如果做得好，这为社会提供了对规则和法律以及秩序的健康尊重，导致低腐败率，并有效地鼓励人们一起工作以提高生产力。国家在这方面做得越好，就越能从生产基本产品转向……
  • … innovating and inventing new technologies. For example, the Dutch were superbly inventive—at their peak they came up with a quarter of all major inventions in the world. One of these were ships that could travel around the globe to collect great riches. They also invented capitalism as we know it. Innovation is generally enhanced by being…
  • …… 创新和发明新技术。例如，荷兰人具有极强的创造力 —— 在他们的巅峰时期，他们想出了世界上所有重大发明的四分之一。其中之一是可以环游世界收集大量财富的船只。他们还发明了我们所知的资本主义。创新通常通过以下方式得到加强……
  • … open to the best thinking in the world to be able to learn the best ways of doing things and by…
  • …… 向世界上最好的思想开放，以便能够学习最好的做事方法，并通过……
  • … the workers, the government, and the military all working well together.
  • …… 工人、政府和军队都能很好地合作。

As a result of all of these things, the country…

由于所有这些事情的结果，国家……

  • … becomes more productive and…
  • …… 变得更有生产力和……
  • … more competitive in world markets, which shows up in its…
  • …… 在世界市场上更具竞争力，这表现在其……
  • … share of world trade rising. You can see this happening today as the US and China are now roughly comparable in both their economic outputs and their shares of world trade.
  • …… 在世界贸易中的份额上升。你可以看到这种情况发生在今天，因为美国和中国现在在其经济产出和世界贸易份额方面都大致相当。
  • As a country trades more globally, it must protect its trade routes and foreign interests and it must be prepared to defend itself from attack so it develops great military strength.
  • 随着一个国家的贸易更加全球化，它必须保护其贸易路线和外国利益，它必须准备保护自己免受攻击，所以它发展了强大的军事力量。

If done well, this virtuous cycle leads to…

如果做得好，这种良性循环会导致……

  • … strong income growth, which can be used to finance…
  • …… 收入增长强劲，可用于资助……
  • … investments in infrastructure, education, and research and development.
  • …… 对基础设施、教育和研究与开发的投资。
  • The country must develop systems to incentivize and empower those who have the ability to make or get wealth. In all of these past cases, the most successful empires used a capitalist approach to incentivize and develop productive entrepreneurs. Even China, which is run by the Chinese Communist Party, uses a state-capitalism approach to incentivize and enable people. To do that incentivizing and financial enabling well, the country…
  • 国家必须制定制度，激励和授权那些有能力创造或获得财富的人。在所有这些过去的案例中，最成功的帝国都使用了资本主义的方法来激励和发展生产性企业家。即使是由中国共产党管理的中国，也采用了国家资本主义的方法来激励和扶持人们。为了做好这种激励和金融扶持，国家……
  • … has to have developing capital markets —most importantly its lending, bond, and stock markets. That allows people to convert their savings into investments to fund innovation and development and share in the successes of those who are making great things happen. The inventive Dutch created the first publicly listed company (the Dutch East India Company) and the first stock market to fund it. These were integral parts of their machine that produced a lot of wealth and power.
  • …… 必须有发展中的资本市场 —— 最重要的是其贷款、债券和股票市场。这使人们能够将他们的储蓄转化为投资，以资助创新和发展，并分享那些正在创造伟大事物的人的成功。富有创造力的荷兰人创建了第一家上市公司（荷兰东印度公司）和第一个股票市场来资助它。这些都是他们产生大量财富和权力的机器中不可或缺的部分。
  • As a natural consequence, all of the greatest empires developed the world’s leading financial center for attracting and distributing the capital of their times. Amsterdam was the world’s financial center when the Dutch were preeminent, London was when the British were on top, New York is now, and China is quickly developing its own financial center in Shanghai.
  • 作为一个自然的结果，所有最伟大的帝国都发展了世界领先的金融中心来吸引和分配其时代的资本。当荷兰人卓越的时候，阿姆斯特丹是世界金融中心；当英国人高高在上的时候，伦敦是世界金融中心；现在，纽约是世界金融中心；而中国正在上海迅速发展自己的金融中心。
  • As the country expands its international dealings to become the largest trading empire, its transactions can be paid in its currency, and people around the world want to save in it, so it becomes the world’s leading reserve currency, which enables the country to borrow more, and at lower rates, than other countries because others want to lend in it.
  • 随着国家扩大其国际交易，成为最大的贸易帝国，其交易可以用其货币支付，世界各地的人都想用它来储蓄，所以它成为世界上最主要的储备货币，这使国家能够比其他国家借到更多、更低的利率，因为其他人想用它贷款。

This series of cause/effect relationships leading to mutually supportive financial, political, and military powers has gone together for as long as there has been recorded history. All of the empires that became the most powerful in the world followed this path to the top.

自从有历史记载以来，这一系列导致相互支持的金融、政治和军事力量的因果关系就一直在进行。所有成为世界上最强大的帝国都是沿着这条道路走向巅峰的。

THE TOP

顶层

In the top phase, the country sustains the successes that fueled its rise, but embedded in the rewards of the successes are the seeds of decline. Over time, obligations pile up, breaking down the self-reinforcing circumstances that fueled the rise.

在顶峰阶段，国家维持着推动其崛起的成功，但在成功的回报中蕴含着衰退的种子。随着时间的推移，义务的堆积，打破了助长崛起的自我强化的环境。

  • As people in the country, which is now rich and powerful, earn more, that makes them more expensive and less competitive relative to people in other countries who are willing to work for less.
  • 由于现在富强的国家的人赚得更多，这使得他们相对于其他国家愿意花更少的钱工作的人来说更昂贵，更没有竞争力。
  • At the same time people from other countries naturally copy the methods and technologies of the leading power, which further reduces the leading country’s competitiveness. For example, British shipbuilders hired Dutch designers to design better ships that were built by less expensive British workers, making them more competitive, which led the British to rise and the Dutch to decline.
  • 同时，其他国家的人自然会复制领先大国的方法和技术，这进一步降低了领先国家的竞争力。例如，英国造船商聘请荷兰设计师设计出更好的船只，由成本更低的英国工人建造，使他们更具竞争力，这导致英国人崛起，荷兰人衰落。
  • Also, as people in the leading country become richer, they tend to not work as hard. They enjoy more leisure, pursue the finer and less productive things in life, and at the extreme become decadent. Values change from generation to generation during the rise to the top—from those who had to fight to achieve wealth and power to those who inherited it. The new generation is less battle-hardened, steeped in luxuries, and accustomed to the easy life, which makes them more vulnerable to challenges.
  • 另外，随着领先国家的人们变得更加富有，他们往往不那么努力工作。他们享受更多的闲暇，追求生活中更美好的东西，而不是生产性的东西，在极端情况下变得颓废。在崛起的过程中，价值观在一代又一代人之间发生了变化 —— 从那些不得不为获得财富和权力而奋斗的人到那些继承了财富和权力的人。新一代人没有那么多战斗经验，沉浸在奢侈品中，习惯于轻松的生活，这使他们更容易受到挑战。
  • Additionally, as people get used to doing well, they increasingly bet on the good times continuing—and borrow money to do that—which leads to financial bubbles.
  • 此外，当人们习惯于做得好的时候，他们越来越多地押注好日子会继续下去 —— 并且借钱来做，这导致了金融泡沫。
  • Within capitalist systems, financial gains come unevenly so the wealth gap grows. Wealth gaps are self-reinforcing because rich people use their greater resources to expand their powers. They also influence the political system to their advantage and give greater privileges to their children—like better education—causing the gaps in values, politics, and opportunity to develop between the rich “haves” and the poor “have-nots.” Those who are less well-off feel the system is unfair so resentments grow.
  • 在资本主义体系内，金融收益的获得是不均衡的，所以财富差距会越来越大。财富差距是自我强化的，因为富人利用他们更大的资源来扩大他们的权力。他们还影响政治制度，使之对自己有利，并给他们的孩子以更大的特权，如更好的教育，导致富人 “有” 和穷人 “无” 之间在价值观、政治和机会方面的差距。那些不那么富裕的人觉得这个系统是不公平的，所以怨恨越来越多。
  • As long as the living standards of most people are still rising, these gaps and resentments don’t boil over into conflict.
  • 只要大多数人的生活水平仍在提高，这些差距和怨恨就不会沸腾成冲突。

During the top, the leading country’s financial picture begins to change. Having a reserve currency gives it the “exorbitant privilege”9 of being able to borrow more money, which gets it deeper into debt. This boosts the leading empire’s spending power over the short term and weakens it over the longer run.

在顶峰时期，主导国家的财政状况开始发生变化。拥有储备货币使其拥有 “过高的特权”9能够借到更多的钱，这使它陷入更深的债务。这在短期内提高了领先帝国的消费能力，而在长期内则削弱了它的实力。

  • Inevitably, the country begins borrowing excessively, which contributes to the country building up large debts with foreign lenders.
  • 不可避免的是，国家开始过度借贷，这促使国家在外国贷款人那里积累了大量债务。
  • While this boosts spending power over the short term, it weakens the country’s financial health—and weakens the currency—over the longer term. In other words, when borrowing and spending are strong, the empire appears very strong, but its finances are in fact being weakened because the borrowing sustains the country’s power beyond its fundamentals by financing both domestic overconsumption and international military conflicts required to maintain the empire.
  • 虽然这在短期内提高了消费能力，但从长期来看，它削弱了国家的财政健康，并削弱了货币。换句话说，当借贷和支出强劲时，帝国看起来非常强大，但它的财政实际上被削弱了，因为借贷通过为国内过度消费和维持帝国所需的国际军事冲突提供资金，使国家的力量超出了其基本面。
  • Also the costs of maintaining and defending the empire become greater than the revenue it brings in, so having an empire becomes unprofitable. For example, the British Empire became massive, bureaucratic, and lost its competitive advantages as rival powers—particularly Germany—soared, leading to an increasingly expensive arms race and world war.
  • 另外，维护和捍卫帝国的成本变得比它带来的收入更大，所以拥有一个帝国变得无利可图。例如，大英帝国变得庞大、官僚化，并随着对手大国 —— 特别是德国 —— 的崛起而失去竞争优势，导致越来越昂贵的军备竞赛和世界战争。
  • The richer countries get into debt by borrowing from poorer countries that save more —that is one of the earliest signs of a wealth and power shift. This started in the United States in the 1980s when it had a per capita income 40 times that of China’s and started borrowing from the Chinese who wanted to save in dollars because the dollar was the world’s reserve currency.
  • 较富裕的国家通过向储蓄较多的贫穷国家借款而陷入债务 —— 这是财富和权力转移的最早迹象之一。这始于 20 世纪 80 年代的美国，当时美国的人均收入是中国的 40 倍，并开始向中国人借款，因为美元是世界储备货币，所以中国人想用美元储蓄。
  • If the empire begins to run out of new lenders, those holding their currency begin to look to sell and get out rather than buy, save, lend, and get in—and the strength of the empire begins to fall.
  • 如果帝国开始耗尽新的贷款人，那些持有其货币的人开始寻求出售和退出，而不是购买、储蓄、贷款和进入，帝国的实力开始下降。

THE DECLINE

下降

The decline phase typically comes from internal economic weakness together with internal fighting, or from costly external fighting, or both. Typically, the country’s decline comes gradually and then suddenly.

衰落阶段通常来自于内部经济衰弱和内部争斗，或来自于昂贵的外部争斗，或两者兼有。通常情况下，国家的衰落是逐渐发生的，然后突然发生。

Internally…

在内部……

  • When debts become very large, and there is an economic downturn and the empire can no longer borrow the money necessary to repay its debts, this creates great domestic hardships and forces the country to choose between defaulting on its debts and printing a lot of new money.
  • 当债务变得非常庞大时，出现经济衰退，帝国无法再借到偿还债务所需的资金，这就造成了巨大的国内困难，迫使国家在拖欠债务和印制大量新钞之间做出选择。
  • The country nearly always chooses to print a lot of new money, at first gradually and eventually massively. This devalues the currency and raises inflation.
  • 国家几乎总是选择印制大量的新货币，起初是逐步印制，最后是大规模印制。这使货币贬值，提高了通货膨胀。
  • Typically at those times when the government has problems funding itself—at the same time as there are bad financial and economic conditions, and large wealth, values, and political gaps—there are great increases in internal conflict between the rich and poor and different ethnic, religious, and racial groups.
  • 通常情况下，当政府的资金出现问题时 —— 在出现糟糕的金融和经济状况，以及巨大的财富、价值观和政治差距的同时，富人和穷人以及不同民族、宗教和种族群体之间的内部冲突也会大大增加。
  • This leads to political extremism that shows up as populism of the left or of the right. Those of the left seek to redistribute the wealth while those of the right seek to maintain the wealth in the hands of the rich. This is the “anti-capitalist phase,” when capitalism, capitalists, and the elites in general are blamed for the problems.
  • 这导致了政治极端主义，表现为左派或右派的民粹主义。左派的人寻求重新分配财富，而右派的人则寻求保持财富在富人手中。这是 “反资本主义阶段”，当资本主义、资本家和一般的精英被指责为问题的根源。
  • Typically during such times taxes on the rich rise, and when the rich fear their wealth and well-being will be taken away, they move to places, assets, and currencies they feel safer in. These outflows reduce the country’s tax revenue, which leads to a classic self-reinforcing, hollowing-out process.
  • 通常在这种时候，对富人的税收会增加，当富人担心他们的财富和福利会被夺走时，他们会转移到他们觉得更安全的地方、资产和货币。这些资金外流减少了国家的税收，这导致了一个典型的自我强化、空洞化的过程。
  • When the flight of wealth gets bad enough, the country outlaws it. Those seeking to get out begin to panic.
  • 当财富外逃变得足够严重时，国家就将其列为非法。那些寻求出逃的人开始恐慌。
  • These turbulent conditions undermine productivity, which shrinks the economic pie and causes more conflict about how to divide the shrinking resources. Populist leaders emerge from both sides and pledge to take control and bring about order. That’s when democracy is most challenged because it fails to control the anarchy and because the move to a strong populist leader who will bring order to the chaos is most likely.
  • 这些动荡的情况破坏了生产力，使经济蛋糕缩小，并在如何分配缩小的资源方面引起更多冲突。民粹主义领导人从双方涌现，并承诺要控制和带来秩序。这时，民主制度受到的挑战最大，因为它无法控制无政府状态，而且最有可能转向一个强大的民粹主义领导人，他将在混乱中带来秩序。
  • As conflict within the country escalates, it leads to some form of revolution or civil war to redistribute wealth and force the big changes. This can be peaceful and maintain the existing internal order, but it’s more often violent and changes the order. For example, the Roosevelt revolution to redistribute wealth was relatively peaceful, while the revolutions that changed the domestic orders in Germany, Japan, Spain, Russia, and China, which also happened in the 1930s for the same reasons, were much more violent.
  • 随着国家内部冲突的升级，它导致了某种形式的革命或内战，以重新分配财富，迫使大变革。这可以是和平的，维持现有的内部秩序，但更多时候是暴力的，改变秩序的。例如，罗斯福为重新分配财富而进行的革命是相对和平的，而在德国、日本、西班牙、俄罗斯和中国发生的改变国内秩序的革命，由于同样的原因也发生在 20 世纪 30 年代，则要暴力的多。

These civil wars and revolutions create what I call new internal orders. I’ll explore how internal orders change in a cyclical way in Chapter 5. But the important thing to note for now is that internal orders can change without leading to a change in the world order. It’s only when the forces that produce internal disorder and instability align with an external challenge that the entire world order can change.

这些内战和革命创造了我所说的新的内部秩序。我将在第五章中探讨内部秩序如何以周期性的方式变化。但现在要注意的是，内部秩序的变化可以不导致世界秩序的变化。只有当产生内部无序和不稳定的力量与外部挑战一致时，整个世界秩序才会发生变化。

Externally…

对外而言……

  • When there is a rising great power that is capable of challenging the existing great power and existing world order, there is a rising risk of great international conflict, especially if there is internal conflict going on within the existing great power. Typically the rising international opponent will seek to exploit this domestic weakness. This is especially risky if the rising international power has built up a comparable military.
  • 当有一个正在崛起的大国能够挑战现有的大国和现有的世界秩序时，巨大的国际冲突的风险就会上升，特别是如果现有的大国内部正在发生内部冲突。通常情况下，崛起的国际对手会试图利用这一国内弱点。如果崛起的国际大国已经建立了相当的军事力量，这就特别有风险。
  • Defending oneself against foreign rivals requires great military spending, which has to occur even as domestic economic conditions are deteriorating and the leading great power country can least afford it.
  • 抵御外国对手需要巨大的军事开支，即使在国内经济状况恶化，领先的大国最不能承受的情况下，也必须进行这种开支。
  • Since there is no viable system for peacefully adjudicating international disputes, these conflicts are typically resolved through tests of power.
  • 由于没有可行的制度来和平裁决国际争端，这些冲突通常通过权力的考验来解决。
  • As bolder challenges are made, the leading empire is faced with the difficult choice of fighting or retreating. Fighting and losing are the worst, but retreating is bad too because it allows the opposition to progress and it shows that one is weak to those other countries that are considering what side to be on.
  • 随着更大胆的挑战被提出，领先的帝国面临着战斗或撤退的艰难选择。战斗和失败是最糟糕的，但撤退也是不好的，因为它允许反对派取得进展，并向那些正在考虑站在哪一边的其他国家表明自己是弱者。
  • Poor economic conditions cause more fighting for wealth and power, which inevitably leads to some kind of war.
  • 糟糕的经济状况导致更多的财富和权力争夺，这不可避免地导致了某种战争的发生。
  • Wars are terribly costly. At the same time, they produce the necessary tectonic shifts that realign the world order to the new reality of wealth and power.
  • 战争的代价是可怕的。同时，它们会产生必要的结构性变化，使世界秩序重新适应财富和权力的新现实。
  • When those holding the reserve currency and debt of the declining empire lose faith and sell them, that marks the end of its Big Cycle.
  • 当那些持有衰落帝国的储备货币和债务的人失去信心并出售它们时，这标志着其大周期的结束。

When all of these forces line up—indebtedness, civil war/revolution at home, war abroad, and a loss of faith in the currency—a change in the world order is typically at hand.

当所有这些力量排在一起时 —— 债务、国内的内战/革命、国外的战争以及对货币失去信心 —— 世界秩序的改变通常就在眼前。

You can see these forces summarized in their typical progression in the following chart.

你可以在下面的图表中看到这些力量的典型进展情况的总结。

I threw a lot at you in the last few pages. You might want to read them again slowly so you can see if the sequence makes sense to you. Later, we will get into a number of specific cases in greater depth and you will see the patterns of these cycles emerge, albeit not in a precise way. The fact that they occur and the reasons for them occurring are less disputable than the exact timing of their occurrences.

我在最后几页中给你扔了很多东西。你可能想再慢慢读一遍，这样你就能看到这个顺序对你是否有意义。稍后，我们将更深入地探讨一些具体案例，你会看到这些周期的模式出现，尽管不是以一种精确的方式。它们发生的事实和它们发生的原因比它们发生的确切时间更容易引起争议。

To summarize, around the upward trend of productivity gains that produce rising wealth and better living standards, there are cycles that produce prosperous periods of building in which the country is fundamentally strong because there are relatively low levels of indebtedness, relatively small wealth, values, and political gaps, people working effectively together to produce prosperity, good education and infrastructure, strong and capable leadership, and a peaceful world order that is guided by one or more dominant world powers. These are the prosperous and enjoyable periods. When they are taken to excess, which they always are, the excesses lead to depressing periods of destruction and restructuring in which the country’s fundamental weaknesses of high levels of indebtedness, large wealth, values, and political gaps, different factions of people unable to work well together, poor education and infrastructure, and the struggle to maintain an overextended empire under the challenge of emerging rivals lead to a painful period of fighting, destruction, and then a restructuring that establishes a new order, setting the stage for a new period of building.

总而言之，围绕着生产力提高的上升趋势，产生了财富的增加和更好的生活水平，有一些周期产生了繁荣的建设时期，其中国家从根本上是强大的，因为有相对较低的负债水平，相对较小的财富、价值观和政治差距，人们有效地共同工作以产生繁荣，良好的教育和基础设施，强大和有能力的领导，以及由一个或多个主导世界大国指导的和平世界秩序。这些都是繁荣和令人愉快的时期。当它们被过度使用时（它们总是被过度使用），就会导致令人沮丧的破坏和重组时期，其中国家的基本弱点是高度负债，巨大的财富、价值观和政治差距，不同派别的人不能很好地合作，糟糕的教育和基础设施，以及在新兴对手的挑战下维持过度扩张的帝国的斗争，导致一个痛苦的战斗、破坏时期，然后进行重组，建立新的秩序，为新的建设时期奠定基础。

Because these steps unfold in a logical sequence of timeless and universal cause/effect relationships, it is possible to create a health index of where a country stands by looking at these measures. When the measures are strong/good, the condition of the country is strong/good and the period ahead is much more likely to be strong/good; when the ratings of these items are weak/bad, the condition of the country is weak/bad and the period ahead is much more likely to be weak/bad.

因为这些步骤是按照永恒的、普遍的因果关系的逻辑顺序展开的，所以通过观察这些措施，有可能建立一个国家所处的健康指数。当这些措施是强/好的时候，国家的状况是强/好的，未来的时期更可能是强/好的；当这些项目的评级是弱/坏的时候，国家的状况是弱/坏的，未来的时期更可能是弱/坏的。

In the following table, to help paint the picture, I converted most of our measures into colors, with dark green being a very favorable reading and dark red being a very unfavorable reading. It is the average of these readings that defines which stage of the cycle a country is in, in much the same way as it is the average of the eight readings of power that I use as my measure of total power. Like those power readings, while one could reconfigure them to produce marginally different readings, they are broadly indicative in a by-and-large way. Here, I am showing this to exemplify the typical process, not to look at any specific case. I will however show specific quantitative readings for all the major countries later in this book.

在下面的表格中，为了帮助描绘画面，我把我们的大部分衡量标准转换成颜色，深绿色是非常有利的读数，深红色是非常不利的读数。这些读数的平均值决定了一个国家处于周期的哪个阶段，就像我用八个权力读数的平均值来衡量总权力一样。就像那些权力读数一样，虽然人们可以重新配置它们以产生略微不同的读数，但它们在很大程度上具有广泛的指示性。在这里，我展示这些是为了示范典型的过程，而不是为了看任何具体的案例。不过，我将在本书后面展示所有主要国家的具体定量解读。

10

Since all of these factors, both ascending and descending, tend to be mutually reinforcing, it is not a coincidence that large wealth gaps, debt crises, revolutions, wars, and changes in the world order have tended to come as a perfect storm. The Big Cycle of an empire’s rise and decline looks like the following chart. The bad periods of destruction and restructuring via depression, revolution, and war, which largely tear down the old system and set the stage for the emergence of a new system, typically take about 10 to 20 years, though variations in the range can be much larger. They are depicted by the shaded areas. They are followed by more extended periods of peace and prosperity in which smart people work harmoniously together and no country wants to fight the world power because it’s too strong. These peaceful periods last for about 40 to 80 years, though variations in the range can be much larger.

由于所有这些因素，包括上升的和下降的，往往是相互加强的，因此，巨大的财富差距、债务危机、革命、战争和世界秩序的变化往往是一个完美的风暴，这并不是一个巧合。一个帝国崛起和衰落的大周期看起来像下面的图表。通过萧条、革命和战争进行破坏和重组的糟糕时期，主要是拆毁旧系统，为新系统的出现创造条件，通常需要 10 到 20 年，尽管范围内的变化可能大得多。阴影部分描述了这些情况。随后是更长时间的和平与繁荣时期，在这个时期，聪明的人们和谐地工作，没有国家因为世界强国太强大而想与之对抗。这些和平时期大约持续 40 到 80 年，尽管范围内的变化可能大得多。

For example, when the Dutch Empire gave way to the British Empire and when the British Empire gave way to the US Empire, most or all of the following things happened:

例如，当荷兰帝国让位给大英帝国，当大英帝国让位给美帝国时，大部分或全部发生了以下事情。

End of the Old, Beginning of the New (e.g., Dutch to British)

旧的结束，新的开始（例如，荷兰人到英国人）。

End of the Old, Beginning of the New (e.g., British to US)

旧的结束，新的开始（例如，英国人到美国）。
  • Debt restructuring and debt crisis
  • 债务重组和债务危机
  • Internal revolution (peaceful or violent) that leads to large transfers of wealth from the “haves” to the “have-nots”
  • 导致财富从 “富人” 向 “穷人” 大量转移的内部革命（和平或暴力）。
  • External war
  • 外部战争
  • Big currency breakdown
  • 大的货币分类
  • New domestic and world order
  • 新的国内和世界秩序
  • Debt restructuring and debt crisis
  • 债务重组和债务危机
  • Internal revolution (peaceful or violent) that leads to large transfers of wealth from the “haves” to the “have-nots”
  • 导致财富从 “富人” 向 “穷人” 大量转移的内部革命（和平或暴力）。
  • External war
  • 外部战争
  • Big currency breakdown
  • 大的货币分类
  • New domestic and world order
  • 新的国内和世界秩序

A PREVIEW OF WHERE WE ARE NOW

预览我们现在的情况

As previously explained, the last major period of destroying and restructuring happened in 1930–45, which led to the period of building and the new world order that began in 1945 with the creation a new global monetary system (built in 1944 in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire) and a US-dominated system of world governance (locating the United Nations in New York and the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington, DC). The new world order was the natural consequence of the US being the richest country (it then had two-thirds of the world’s gold stock and gold was then money), the dominant economic power (it then accounted for about half of world production), and the strongest military (it then had a monopoly on nuclear weapons and the strongest conventional forces).

如前所述，上一个主要的破坏和重组时期发生在 1930 年至 1945 年，这导致了 1945 年开始的建设和世界新秩序时期，建立了新的全球货币体系（1944 年在新罕布什尔州的布雷顿森林建立）和美国主导的世界治理体系（将联合国设在纽约，世界银行和国际货币基金组织设在华盛顿特区）。新的世界秩序是美国作为最富有的国家（它当时拥有世界上三分之二的黄金存量，黄金当时就是货币）、占主导地位的经济大国（它当时占世界产量的一半左右）和最强大的军队（它当时垄断了核武器和最强大的常规部队）的自然结果。

At the time of my writing, it is now 75 years later, and the major old empires, which are also the major reserve currency empires, are classically approaching the end of a long-term debt cycle when there are large debts and typical monetary policies don’t work well. Politically fragmented central governments have recently tried to fill in their financial holes by giving out a lot of money that they are borrowing, while central banks have tried to help by printing a lot of money (i.e., monetizing government debt). All this is happening when there are big wealth and values gaps and a rising world power that is competing with the leading world power in trade, technology development, capital markets, and geopolitics. And on top of all this, as of this writing we have a pandemic to contend with.

在我写这篇文章的时候，现在已经过了 75 年，主要的老牌帝国，也是主要的储备货币帝国，在有大量债务和典型的货币政策不能很好地发挥作用时，经典地接近长期债务周期的终点。政治上四分五裂的中央政府最近试图通过发放大量借来的钱来填补其财政漏洞，而中央银行则试图通过印制大量货币（即政府债务货币化）来提供帮助。所有这些都是在存在巨大的财富和价值观差距，以及一个正在崛起的世界大国在贸易、技术发展、资本市场和地缘政治方面与世界领先大国竞争的情况下发生的。而在这一切的基础上，截至本文写作时，我们还有一场大流行病要对付。

Simultaneously, great human thinking, working with computer intelligence, is creating great ways of addressing these challenges. If we can all deal with each other well, we will certainly get past this difficult time and move on to a new prosperous period that will be quite different. At the same time, I am equally confident that there will be radical changes that will be traumatic for many people.

同时，伟大的人类思维，与计算机智能合作，正在创造解决这些挑战的伟大方法。如果我们都能很好地处理彼此之间的关系，我们肯定会度过这个困难时期，并进入一个新的繁荣时期，这将是相当不同的。同时，我也同样相信，会有激进的变化，对许多人来说是一种创伤。

That is how the world works in a nutshell. Now I will give a more expanded description.

这就是这个世界的运作方式，简而言之。现在我将作一个更广泛的描述。

5 At this time, humanity is evolving its ways of thinking and increasing productivity in more dramatic ways than ever before—even more dramatically than the discovery and usage of the scientific method. We are doing this through the development of artificial intelligence, which is an alternative way of thinking via an alternative brain that can make discoveries and process them into instructions of what should be done. Humanity is essentially creating an alternative species that has enormous capacity to see past patterns and process many different ideas very quickly, has little or no common sense, has trouble understanding the logic behind relationships, and doesn’t have emotions. This species is simultaneously smart and stupid, helpful and dangerous. It offers great potential and needs to be well-controlled and not blindly followed.

5此时此刻，人类正在以前所未有的方式进化其思维方式和提高生产力 —— 甚至比科学方法的发现和使用更加引人注目。我们是通过人工智能的发展来做到这一点的，人工智能是一种通过另类大脑的另类思维方式，它可以做出发现并将其处理为应该做的指示。人类本质上正在创造一个替代物种，它有巨大的能力看到过去的模式，并非常迅速地处理许多不同的想法，几乎没有常识，难以理解关系背后的逻辑，而且没有情感。这个物种既聪明又愚蠢，既有益又危险。它提供了巨大的潜力，需要被很好地控制，而不是盲目追随。

6 In 2008, it took two months from the crash to the printing of money; in 2020, it took just weeks.

62008 年，从崩盘到印钞花了两个月；2020 年，只花了几个星期。

7 These indices are made up of a number of different statistics, some of which are directly comparable and some of which are broadly analogous or broadly indicative. In some cases, a data series that stopped at a certain point had to be spliced with a series that continued back in time. Additionally, the lines shown on the chart are 30-year moving averages of these indices, shifted so that there is no lag. I chose to use the smoothed series because the volatility of the unsmoothed series was too great to allow one to see the big movements. Going forward, I will use these very smoothed versions when looking at the very long term and much less smoothed or unsmoothed versions when looking at these developments up close because the most important developments are best captured this way.

7这些指数是由一些不同的统计数据组成的，其中一些是可以直接比较的，另一些则是大体上可以类比或大体上可以指示的。在某些情况下，停止在某一点的数据系列必须与继续往前的系列进行拼接。此外，图表上显示的线条是这些指数的 30 年移动平均线，移位后就没有滞后了。我选择使用平滑的系列，因为未经平滑的系列的波动性太大，让人无法看到大的运动。今后，我将在观察非常长期的情况时使用这些非常平滑的版本，而在近距离观察这些发展时，则使用平滑或未平滑的版本，因为最重要的发展是以这种方式得到的。

8 We show where key indicators were relative to their history by averaging them across the cases. The chart is shown such that a value of 1 represents the peak in that indicator relative to history and 0 represents the trough. The timeline is shown in years with 0 representing roughly when the country was at its peak (i.e., when the average across the gauges was at its peak). In the rest of this chapter, we walk through each of the stages of the archetype in more detail.

8我们通过对所有案例的平均数来显示关键指标相对于其历史的位置。图表显示，1 的值代表该指标相对于历史的峰值，0 代表低谷。时间轴以年为单位，0 代表国家处于高峰时（即各指标的平均数处于高峰时）的大致情况。在本章的其余部分，我们将更详细地介绍该原型的每个阶段。

9 “Exorbitant privilege” is a way of describing a reserve currency that was coined by French Finance Minister Valéry Giscard d’Estaing as a description of the position of the US.

9“高昂的特权” 是法国财政部长瓦莱里·吉斯卡尔·德斯坦创造的一种描述储备货币的方式，是对美国地位的描述。

10 Acts of nature, external order, and geology are not included in cycle analysis. Readings use proxies for determinants with limited history.

10自然界的行为、外部秩序和地质学不包括在周期分析中。读书会使用历史有限的决定因素的代用资料。

CHAPTER 2 THE DETERMINANTS

第二章决定因素

I n the last chapter I described the Big Cycle in a tiny nutshell. In this and the other chapters that follow in Part I, I will flesh out how I see the perpetual-motion machine working. In this chapter, I will review the most important determinants and summarize how I put them into my “model.”

I 在上一章中，我对大循环做了一个小小的概括描述。在这一章和第一部分后面的其他章节中，我将充实说明我认为永动机是如何工作的。在这一章中，我将回顾最重要的决定因素，并总结我是如何将它们纳入我的 “模型” 的。

As the saying goes, and most people agree, “history rhymes.” It “rhymes” because its most important events repeat, though never in exactly the same way. That is because, while the cause/effect relationships behind those events are timeless and universal, all things evolve and influence each other in different ways. By studying many analogous events in different times and places, their underlying causes and effects become clearer. I have learned that history’s continuously evolving story transpires like a perpetual-motion machine that is driven by cause/effect relationships that both evolve and repeat over time.

俗话说，大多数人都同意，“历史是押韵的”。它之所以 “押韵”，是因为其最重要的事件会重复发生，尽管从来没有以完全相同的方式。这是因为，虽然这些事件背后的因果关系是永恒的、普遍的，但所有事物都以不同的方式相互演变和影响。通过研究不同时间和地点的许多类似事件，其根本原因和影响变得更加清晰。我了解到，历史上不断演变的故事就像一台永动机，由因果关系驱动，随着时间的推移不断发展和重复。

To deal with the realities that are coming at me, my process is to…

为了应对向我袭来的现实，我的过程是……

  • Interact with this machine and try to understand how it works
  • 与这台机器互动，尝试了解它的工作原理
  • Write down my observations of its workings, along with the principles I have learned for dealing with them
  • 写下我对其工作原理的观察，以及我学到的处理这些问题的原则
  • Backtest those principles through time
  • 通过时间对这些原则进行回测
  • Convert the principles into equations and program them into a computer that helps me with my decision making
  • 将原理转化为方程式，并将其编入计算机，帮助我进行决策。
  • Learn from my experiences and my reflections on my experiences, so I can refine my principles
  • 从我的经验和我对经验的反思中学习，以便我能够完善我的原则
  • Do that over and over again
  • 一遍又一遍地这样做

Imagine a chess player who records their criteria for making different moves in different situations, which they then encode into a computer that plays alongside them like a partner. Each player brings what they are best at to the game. The human player is more inventive, more lateral in thinking, and better able to reason, while the computer can calculate more data faster, is better able to identify patterns, and is much less emotional. This never-ending process of learning, building, using, and refining in partnership with computers describes what I do, except my game is global macro investing, not chess.

想象一下，一个棋手记录了自己在不同情况下走不同棋步的标准，然后将其编码到计算机中，像伙伴一样与他们一起下棋。每个棋手都把自己最擅长的东西带到游戏中。人类棋手更有创造力，思维更横向，推理能力更强，而计算机能更快地计算更多的数据，更能识别模式，并且更少情绪化。这种与计算机合作学习、建立、使用和完善的永无止境的过程描述了我的工作，只不过我的游戏是全球宏观投资，而不是国际象棋。

In this chapter, I will share my description of the workings of the perpetual-motion machine that drives the rises and declines of empires and their reserve currencies as I have come to understand it thus far, giving you a glimpse into how I play my game. While I’m sure my mental model is wrong and incomplete in any number of ways, it is the best one that I have now and it has proven invaluable to me. I am passing it along for you to probe and explore, take or leave, and build on as you like. My hope is that I will prompt you and others to think about the timeless and universal cause/effect relationships that drive the realities that are coming at us, and the best principles for dealing with them. By stress testing and improving this model through full-throated debate, we will get to the point where we have a largely agreed-upon template of the processes and their causes. By using that template, we can then strive to agree on which stage each country is in and what the best practices are for interacting with it, whether we are individuals taking care of our own interests or we are leaders taking care of our country’s.

在这一章中，我将分享我对推动帝国及其储备货币兴衰的永动机工作原理的描述，这是我迄今为止对它的理解，让你了解我是如何玩我的游戏的。虽然我确信我的心理模型在任何方面都是错误和不完整的，但这是我现在拥有的最好的模型，而且它已被证明对我非常宝贵。我把它传递给你，让你去探究和探索，接受或离开，并在你喜欢的基础上发展。我的希望是，我将促使你和其他人思考那些推动正在向我们走来的现实的永恒和普遍的因果关系，以及处理它们的最佳原则。通过充分的辩论，对这一模式进行压力测试和改进，我们将达到这样的程度，即我们有一个基本一致的过程及其原因的模板。通过使用该模板，我们可以努力就每个国家所处的阶段以及与之互动的最佳做法达成一致，无论我们是个人照顾自己的利益，还是我们是领导人照顾国家的利益。

In the last chapter, I conveyed a very simplified description of the determinants of the evolution and cyclical rises and declines of empires—most importantly, what I believe to be the primary drivers of the Big Cycles. In this chapter, I will explain the model in much greater detail. It is based on what I saw happen repeatedly through time in the 11 leading empires of the last 500 years, the 20 most important countries of the last 100 years, and the major dynasties of China over the last 1,400 years. To be clear, I do not consider myself to be an expert historian in these cases, and these cases represent only a small percentage of all cases. I only glanced at some of the most important empires in early history, such as the Roman, Greek, Egyptian, Byzantine, Mongol, Han, Sui, Arab, and Persian empires, and I completely neglected many of the other empires that have risen and declined throughout the world in Africa, South Asia, the Pacific Islands, and precolonial North and South America. In other words, what I didn’t examine was much greater than what I did examine. Still, I believe I have seen enough to develop a good mental model that applies to most countries, which has been very helpful to my efforts to understand what is going on today and which helps me to form a valuable, though hazy, picture of the future.

在上一章中，我传达了对帝国演变和周期性兴衰的决定因素的非常简化的描述 —— 最重要的是，我认为大周期的主要驱动因素是什么。在本章中，我将更详细地解释这个模型。它是基于我看到的过去 500 年中 11 个主要帝国、过去 100 年中 20 个最重要的国家以及过去 1400 年中中国的主要朝代中反复发生的事情。要明确的是，我不认为自己是这些案例的历史专家，而且这些案例只占所有案例的一小部分。我只瞥了一眼早期历史上最重要的一些帝国，如罗马、希腊、埃及、拜占庭、蒙古、汉、隋、阿拉伯和波斯帝国，我完全忽略了非洲、南亚、太平洋岛屿和殖民前的南北美洲等世界各地兴起和衰落的许多其他帝国。换句话说，我没有研究的东西比我研究的东西要大得多。尽管如此，我相信我已经看到了足够多的东西，从而形成了一个适用于大多数国家的良好心智模式，这对我了解今天发生的事情非常有帮助，这有助于我对未来形成一个有价值的、尽管是朦胧的画面。

THE CONSTRUCTION OF MY MENTAL MODEL OF THE PERPETUAL-MOTION MACHINE

构建我对永动机的心理模型

Just as we can see the arc of the human life cycle from birth to death and how one generation impacts the next, we can do the same with countries and empires. We can see how values, assets, liabilities, and experiences are handed down and how their evolutionary effects ripple out across the generations. We can tell when an empire is approaching its peak and when it is in decline.

正如我们可以看到人类生命周期从出生到死亡的弧线，以及一代人如何影响下一代，我们可以对国家和帝国做同样的事情。我们可以看到价值、资产、负债和经验是如何传承的，以及它们的进化效应是如何在几代人之间产生涟漪的。我们可以知道一个帝国何时接近顶峰，何时走向衰落。

●All peoples throughout history have had systems or orders for governing how they deal with each other. I call the systems within countries “internal orders,” those between countries “external orders,” and those that apply to the whole world “world orders.” These orders affect each other and are always changing. Such orders have always existed at every level—within families, companies, cities, states, and countries, as well as internationally. They determine who has what powers and how decisions are made, including how wealth and political control are divided. What they are and how they run is a function of human nature, culture, and circumstances. The US now has a certain set of existing political conditions within its democratic system, but both the conditions and the system are ever-changing because of the pressure of timeless and universal forces.

●历史上所有的民族都有管理他们如何处理彼此关系的制度或命令。我把国家内部的制度称为 “内部秩序”，国家之间的制度称为 “外部秩序”，而那些适用于整个世界的制度称为 “世界秩序”。这些秩序相互影响，并且一直在变化。这种秩序一直存在于各个层面 —— 在家庭、公司、城市、州和国家，以及国际上。它们决定了谁拥有什么权力以及如何做出决定，包括如何划分财富和政治控制权。它们是什么，如何运行，是人类本性、文化和环境的一个功能。美国现在在其民主制度内有一套现有的政治条件，但由于永恒的和普遍的力量的压力，条件和制度都在不断变化。

The way I see it, at any moment in time there are both 1) the existing set of conditions that include the existing domestic and world orders and 2) timeless and universal forces that cause changes in these conditions. Most people tend to pay too much attention to what exists relative to the timeless and universal forces that produce the changes. I do the opposite in my attempt to anticipate change. Everything that has happened and everything that will happen has had and will have determinants that make it happen. If we can understand those determinants, we can understand how the machine works and anticipate what will likely be coming at us next.

在我看来，在任何时候，都有 1）包括现有的国内和世界秩序在内的一系列现有条件，以及 2）导致这些条件变化的永恒和普遍的力量。大多数人倾向于过分关注相对于产生变化的永恒和普遍的力量而言存在的东西。我在试图预测变化时则相反。已经发生的一切和将要发生的一切都有并将有决定因素使其发生。如果我们能理解这些决定因素，我们就能理解机器是如何工作的，并预测接下来可能会发生的事情。

Since everything that happened and will happen was and is due to the interactions of the parts of this perpetual-motion machine, one can say that everything is predestined. I believe that, if we had a perfect model that took every cause/effect relationship into consideration, we could perfectly forecast the future—that the only thing that stands in the way is our inability to model all those cause/effect dynamics. While that might or might not be right, it tells you where I’m coming from and what I’m striving for.

由于所有已经发生和将要发生的事情都是由于这个永动机各部分的相互作用而造成的，因此可以说一切都已注定。我相信，如果我们有一个完美的模型，把每一个因果关系都考虑进去，我们就可以完美地预测未来 —— 唯一的障碍是我们没有能力建立所有这些因果动态的模型。虽然这可能是也可能不是正确的，但它告诉你我的出发点和我的努力方向。

Most people don’t see things that way. Most people believe the future is unknowable and that destiny doesn’t exist. To be clear, while having a perfect model that gives a nearly perfect picture of that predestined future would be great, I don’t expect my model to come close to that. My goal is simply to have a crude yet evolving model that gives me a leg up relative to the competition and relative to the position I would be in if I didn’t have the model.

大多数人并不这样看问题。大多数人认为未来是不可知的，命运不存在。明确地说，虽然有一个完美的模型，对那个注定的未来给出一个近乎完美的描述，那将是非常好的，但我并不期望我的模型能接近这个目标。我的目标仅仅是拥有一个粗略但不断发展的模型，使我在竞争中获得优势，并且相对于我没有这个模型的情况下会处于的地位而言。

To build this model, I looked at history quantitatively as well as qualitatively because 1) by measuring conditions and their changes, I can more objectively determine the cause/effect relationships behind them, develop a likely range of expectations, and systemize my decision making accordingly but 2) I can’t measure everything quantitatively.

为了建立这个模型，我对历史进行了定量和定性的研究，因为 1）通过测量条件和它们的变化，我可以更客观地确定它们背后的因果关系，制定一个可能的预期范围，并相应地使我的决策系统化，但 2）我不可能定量地测量一切。

My process is to look at many cases to observe how their determinants created the effects that define them. To give a simple example, a lot of debt (a determinant) together with tight money (another determinant) will typically produce a debt crisis (the effect). Similarly, when the three big cycles that I described in the last chapter come together in a bad way (heavy indebtedness with the central bank printing a lot of money; internal conflict stemming from gaps in wealth, values, and politics; and the rise of one or more competing powers), that typically leads to the decline of an incumbent empire.

我的过程是观察许多案例，观察它们的决定因素是如何产生定义它们的效果的。举个简单的例子，大量的债务（一个决定因素）加上紧缩的货币（另一个决定因素）通常会产生债务危机（效果）。同样，当我在上一章中描述的三个大周期以一种糟糕的方式结合在一起时（沉重的债务与中央银行大量印钞；由财富、价值观和政治差距引起的内部冲突；以及一个或多个竞争势力的崛起），这通常会导致一个在位帝国的衰落。

In my mental model, the relationship between the determinants and their effects in the various cases looks like this:

在我的思维模式中，各种情况下的决定因素和它们的影响之间的关系是这样的。

How the Machine Works = (f)…

 

Case

案例

1

1

Case

案例

2

2

Case

案例

3

3

4

效果

效果

Effect

效果

Effect

效果

Effect

效果

Effect

效果

Etc

等

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Determinants lead to effects that become subsequent determinants that produce subsequent effects that become linked together in many cases. So we can look at each case and see what happened (the effect) and what made it happen (its determinants). Or we can look at the determinants to see the effects they had to make up the various cases. The determinants are both what exists and the energy that produces changes; like energy and matter, at the end of the day they’re the same. They create new circumstances and new determinants that create the next changes.

决定因素导致了效果，而效果又成为后续的决定因素，产生了后续的效果，这些效果在很多情况下是联系在一起的。因此，我们可以观察每个案例，看看发生了什么（效果），以及是什么让它发生（它的决定因素）。或者我们可以看一下决定因素，看看它们对各种案例产生的影响。决定因素既是存在的东西，也是产生变化的能量；就像能量和物质一样，到最后它们都是一样的。他们创造了新的环境和新的决定因素，创造了下一个变化。

That is how I quite literally try to model the perpetual-motion machine.

这就是我试图对永动机进行建模的方式。

THE 3, THE 5, THE 8, AND THE 18 DETERMINANTS

3、5、8 和 18 的决定因素

In the last chapter, I introduced you to what I believe are the three big cycles and the eight most important determinants of the rises and declines of empires and their currencies. Because thinking about all of these determinants and their interactions is complex, I suggest that you keep the three big cycles in mind as the most important things to watch: 1) the cycle of good and bad finances (e.g., the capital markets cycle), 2) the cycle of internal order and disorder (due to degrees of cooperation and fighting over wealth and power largely caused by wealth and values gaps), and 3) the cycle of external order and disorder (due to the degrees of the competitiveness of existing powers in fighting for wealth and power). I hope you will join me in trying to understand these three cycles and know where countries are in them. History and logic show that when a country simultaneously has all three in their good phases it is strong and rising, and when all three are in their bad phases it is weak and declining.

在上一章中，我向你介绍了我认为的三个大周期和帝国及其货币兴衰的八个最重要的决定因素。由于对所有这些决定因素及其相互作用的思考是复杂的，我建议你把三个大周期作为最重要的事情来关注。1）好的和坏的财政周期（例如，资本市场周期），2）内部秩序和无序的周期（由于主要由财富和价值差距引起的合作和争夺财富和权力的程度），以及 3）外部秩序和无序的周期（由于现有大国争夺财富和权力的竞争程度）。我希望你能和我一起尝试了解这三个周期，并知道各国在其中的位置。历史和逻辑表明，当一个国家同时拥有这三者的良好阶段时，它就会强大和上升，而当这三者都处于不良阶段时，它就会衰弱和下降。

If I were to add two more determinants to keep in mind, they would be 4) the pace of innovation and technological development to solve problems and make improvements and 5) acts of nature, most importantly droughts, floods, and diseases. That is because innovation and technological advances can solve most problems and further evolution, and acts of nature such as droughts, floods, and diseases have had enormous impacts throughout history. These are the five most important forces, which I call the “Big Five,” so when they are moving in the same direction—toward improving or toward worsening—most everything else follows.

如果我还要加上两个决定因素，那就是 4）创新和技术发展的步伐，以解决问题并进行改进；5）自然行为，最重要的是干旱、洪水和疾病。这是因为创新和技术进步可以解决大多数问题并进一步进化，而自然行为，如干旱、洪水 和疾病，在历史上产生了巨大影响。这是最重要的五种力量，我称之为 “五大力量”，因此，当它们朝着同一方向发展时 —— 朝向改善或朝向恶化 —— 大多数其他事物都会随之而来。

I also introduced the eight powers that I could measure that seemed to be the most important. You can review them along with the big cycles in the following list. These indicators both reflect and drive the upswings and downswings. The chart of the archetypical rise and decline by factor in Chapter 1 showed the average readings of these along the path of the archetypical cycle. Each of these types of power rising and declining in cycles comes together with the other cycles to make the one Big Cycle of the empire’s rise and decline.

我还介绍了我可以衡量的似乎是最重要的八种力量。你可以在下面的列表中与大周期一起回顾它们。这些指标既反映也推动了上升和下降。第一章中按因素划分的原型上升和下降的图表显示了这些沿着原型周期的路径的平均读数。每种类型的权力上升和下降的周期与其他周期一起构成了帝国上升和下降的一个大周期。

And then there are the other determinants such as geology/geography, rule of law, and infrastructure that matter too. The whole list of 18 factors 1 included in my model is shown on the next page. You can also read a detailed description of all 18 at the end of Chapter 14.

然后还有其他决定因素，如地质/地理、法治和基础设施也很重要。我的模型中包含的18 个因素的全部清单 1 在我的模型中包括的全部 18 个因素，见下一页。你也可以在第 14 章末尾阅读所有 18 个因素的详细描述。

I find measuring and weighing all these things in my head, plus all of the other important dynamics at play, to be impossible. That is why I analyze them with the aid of a computer. I will share my analysis for the top 11 countries in the appendix after Chapter 14: The Future. I also provide detail on some components for the top 20 countries at economicprinciples.org.

我发现在我的头脑中测量和权衡所有这些东西，再加上所有其他重要的动态因素，是不可能的。这就是为什么我在计算机的帮助下对它们进行分析。我将在第 14 章：未来之后的附录中分享我对前 11 个国家的分析。我还在economicprinciples.org网站上提供了关于前 20 名国家的一些组成部分的细节。

Though none of these determinants is determinative on its own, I think you will find that when considered together they paint a pretty clear picture of which part of its life cycle a country is in and the direction it is headed in. For the fun of it you might want to go through a little exercise of ticking off where each of those measures is for each country you’re interested in. Rank each country on a 1–10 scale for each attribute, beginning with 10 on the far left and 1 on the far right. If you add all these rankings up, the higher the number, the greater the probability of the country rising on a relative basis. The lower the number, the more likely it will fall. Take a moment to calculate where the United States is, where China is, where Italy is, where Brazil is, and so on.

虽然这些决定性因素本身并不具有决定性，但我认为你会发现，如果把它们放在一起考虑，就会很清楚地看到一个国家处于生命周期的哪个阶段，以及它的发展方向。为了好玩，你可能想通过一个小练习，勾出你感兴趣的每个国家的这些措施的位置。对每个国家的每个属性进行 1-10 的排名，从最左边的 10 开始，最右边的 1。如果你把所有这些排名加起来，数字越高，这个国家在相对基础上上升的可能性就越大。数字越低，就越有可能下降。花点时间计算一下美国在哪里，中国在哪里，意大利在哪里，巴西在哪里，等等。

Because I systematize as much as I can, I push to quantify whatever possible into a decision-making system. So, with the help of my team, I have developed gauges that look at things like internal and external conflict, political gaps, etc., to help me better understand where countries are in their cycles. Some of the less key determinants are aggregated as subcomponents of the key determinants.

因为我尽可能地将其系统化，我推动将任何可能的东西量化为决策系统。因此，在我的团队的帮助下，我开发了一些衡量标准，如内部和外部冲突、政治差距等，以帮助我更好地了解国家在其周期中的位置。一些不太关键的决定因素被汇总为关键决定因素的子组成部分。

While I measure and describe the determinants discretely, they are not separate. They interact with each other and blend together, typically reinforcing each other and the whole cycle’s rise and fall. For example, stronger education leads to stronger technological innovation, which leads to increased productivity and increased shares of trade, greater wealth, more military power, and eventually the establishment of a reserve currency. Further, having strong leaders, a population that is well-educated and civil with each other, a system that efficiently allocates capital and other resources, access to natural resources, and favorable geography all help a lot, and when they decline, they tend to decline together.

虽然我对这些决定因素进行了单独的测量和描述，但它们并不是独立的。它们相互作用，融为一体，通常会相互加强，整个周期的兴衰也会相互加强。例如，更强的教育导致更强的技术创新，从而导致生产力的提高和贸易份额的增加，更大的财富，更多的军事力量，并最终建立一个储备货币。此外，拥有强大的领导人，受过良好教育和相互之间文明的人口，有效分配资本和其他资源的系统，获得自然资源，以及有利的地理环境都有很大的帮助，当它们衰落时，它们往往会一起衰落。

Of course, not all of the indicators can be expressed in numbers and equations; things like human nature and the power dynamics that affect behaviors and outcomes are better described in words. I call these things dynamics. The following table shows a list of other main dynamics that I keep in my head while trying to evaluate where nations are and what is likely to come next.

当然，并不是所有的指标都可以用数字和方程式来表达；像人性和影响行为和结果的权力动态，最好用文字来描述。我把这些东西称为动力。下表显示了我在试图评估各国所处的位置和接下来可能发生的事情时，脑海中保持的其他主要动态的清单。

That’s a lot. It is both too little and too much—too little to do full justice to the subjects (which have all been the focus of whole books and doctoral theses) and too much to process and digest. I have tried to cram a small portion of what I’ve learned about them into the summaries that follow. Fuller accounts of a number of these dynamics are contained in an addendum immediately following this chapter if you’re interested in diving more deeply into any of them. While I’m sure that what follows doesn’t include all the most important determinants, I also know that the ones I’m highlighting here and in the following chapters represent the most important influences that have repeatedly driven the most important events throughout history. Of course, I look forward to being corrected and guided by others to make my descriptions more complete.

这是个很大的数字。它既少又多 —— 少到无法完全公正地描述这些主题（它们都是整本书和博士论文的重点），多到无法处理和消化。我试图将我所了解到的一小部分内容塞进后面的摘要中。如果你有兴趣更深入地了解其中任何一个动态，本章后面的附录中会有对其中一些动态的更全面描述。虽然我确信下面的内容并不包括所有最重要的决定因素，但我也知道，我在这里和下面的章节中强调的那些决定因素代表了最重要的影响因素，它们在历史上反复推动了最重要的事件。当然，我期待着得到别人的纠正和指导，使我的描述更加完整。

EXPLORING THE DETERMINANTS AND DYNAMICS

探讨决定因素和动态

I find that knowing the different circumstances countries face, as well as the strategies and group dynamics they bring to facing these circumstances, helps me understand what moves are likely to come next and how these moves will impact the key determinants. I will explain a bit more about how these look to me, which I will do by examining the machine from the top down.

我发现，了解各国所面临的不同情况，以及他们面对这些情况所带来的策略和群体动态，有助于我理解接下来可能会有哪些举动，以及这些举动将如何影响关键决定因素。我将更多地解释一下这些在我看来是怎么回事，我将通过自上而下地检查机器来做到这一点。

As I see it, the determinants and dynamics that drive events fall into two types:

在我看来，推动事件发生的决定因素和动力分为两类。

  1. 1. Inherited Determinants: They include a country’s geography, geology, and acts of nature such as weather and diseases.
  2. 1. 遗传性决定因素。它们包括一个国家的地理、地质和自然行为，如天气和疾病。
  3. 2. Human Capital Determinants: They are the ways people are with themselves and each other. They are driven by human nature and different cultures (which differentiate their approaches).
  4. 2. 人力资本决定因素。它们是人们与自己和彼此之间的相处方式。它们是由人性和不同的文化（使其方法不同）所驱动。

These two big categories contain within them many important factors, ranging from qualities that are highly specific to countries (like their geography) to those that are universal (like the human tendency to favor short-term gratification over long-term goals), and they can be discerned at every level, whether in individuals, cities, countries, or empires.

这两大类包含了许多重要的因素，从国家高度特有的品质（如地理）到普遍的品质（如人类倾向于短期满足而非长期目标），它们可以在每个层面上被发现，无论是在个人、城市、国家还是帝国。

INHERITED DETERMINANTS

遗传性决定因素

By inherited determinants of a country’s well-being I mean its geography, geology, genealogy, and acts of nature. These are big drivers of each country’s and each people’s stories. For example, you can’t understand the success of the United States without recognizing that it is separated from European and Asian powers by two oceans and blessed with most of the minerals, metals, and other natural resources it needs to be prosperous and self-sufficient, including the topsoil, water, and temperate climate that allows it to produce most of its own food. These factors enabled it to be largely isolationist until a little more than a century ago while investing in education, infrastructure, and innovation in ways that made it strong. Let’s briefly review those.

我所说的一个国家的福祉的继承性决定因素是指其地理、地质、族谱和自然行为。这些是每个国家和每个民族的故事的重要驱动力。例如，如果不认识到美国与欧洲和亚洲大国隔着两大洋，并且拥有繁荣和自给自足所需的大部分矿物、金属和其他自然资源，包括使其能够生产大部分食物的表土、水和温带气候，你就无法理解美国的成功。这些因素使其在一个多世纪前在很大程度上是孤立主义的，同时在教育、基础设施和创新方面的投资使其强大。让我们简单回顾一下这些。

1. Geography. Where a country is, what’s around it, and what its terrain is like are all important determinants. For example, the geographies of the United States and China—both with large expanses of land bounded by large natural barriers of water and mountains—created the inclination for them to be one big whole, increasing the commonalities of their people (e.g., shared language, government, culture, etc.). In contrast, the geography of Europe (i.e., having many more natural boundaries within it) reinforced its divisions into different states/countries, leading to fewer commonalities among its people (e.g., different languages, governments, cultures, etc.).

1.1. 地理环境。一个国家在哪里，它周围有什么，它的地形是什么样的，都是重要的决定因素。例如，美国和中国的地理环境 —— 都有大片土地被水和山的巨大自然屏障所包围 —— 使它们倾向于成为一个大整体，增加了人民的共性（例如，共同的语言、政府、文化等）。相比之下，欧洲的地理环境（即在其内部有更多的自然边界）加强了其对不同国家/民族的划分，导致其人民之间的共同点减少（例如，不同的语言、政府、文化等）。

2. Geology. The natural resources on and under a country’s surface are critically important, but geology should not be overvalued relative to human capital. History shows us that every commodity has declined in value (in inflation-adjusted terms) with big up and down cycles around that downtrend. That is because inventiveness changes what is in demand—e.g., new energy sources replacing old ones, fiber-optic cable replacing copper wiring, etc.—and natural resources are depleted over time. Many Middle Eastern countries’ wealth, power, and relevance to the rest of the world rose with the importance of petroleum and may fall as the world turns away from fossil fuels. The most vulnerable position to be in is having a high reliance on one or a few commodities because they are highly cyclical and sometimes lose value altogether.

2.2. 地质学。一个国家地表和地下的自然资源是极其重要的，但相对于人力资本而言，地质学不应该被高估。历史告诉我们，每一种商品的价值都在下降（按通货膨胀调整后的价值计算），在这一下降趋势周围有很大的上升和下降周期。这是因为创造性改变了需求 —— 例如，新能源取代了旧能源，光纤电缆取代了铜线，等等 —— 而自然资源则随着时间的推移而耗尽。许多中东国家的财富、权力和与世界其他国家的相关性随着石油的重要性而上升，并可能随着世界远离化石燃料而下降。最脆弱的处境是对一种或几种商品的高度依赖，因为它们具有高度的周期性，有时会完全失去价值。

3. Acts of Nature. Acts of nature come in many forms, such as epidemic diseases, floods, and droughts. Throughout history they have affected the well-being of countries and the course of their evolution even more than wars and depressions. The Black Death killed an estimated 75–200 million people in the years around 1350, and smallpox killed more than 300 million people in the 20th century, which is more than double the number that died in its wars. Droughts and floods have caused massive famines and loss of life. Such catastrophes tend to come along unexpectedly and act as stress tests, revealing the underlying strengths and weaknesses of societies.

3.3. 自然行为。自然界的行为有很多形式，如流行病、洪水和干旱。纵观历史，它们对国家的福祉和演变过程的影响甚至超过了战争和萧条。黑死病在 1350 年左右的几年里估计杀死了 7.5-2 亿人，而天花在 20 世纪杀死了 3 亿多人，这比在战争中死亡的人数多了一倍。干旱和洪水造成了大规模的饥荒和生命损失。这种灾难往往出乎意料地出现，并作为压力测试，揭示了社会的潜在力量和弱点。

4. Genealogy. Regarding genealogy, I’m no expert on genetics, so I have little to offer other than to say that all people come into this world with inherited genes that affect how they behave to some extent, so it is logical that the genetic makeup of a country’s population should have some effect on its outcomes. Having said that, I should point out that most of the evidence I have seen indicates that only a small percentage (15 percent or less) of the variations in the behaviors of people between populations could potentially be explained by genetic differences, so genetics seems to be a relatively minor determinant in relation to the other influences I am mentioning.

4. 谱系。关于家谱，我不是遗传学专家，所以我没有什么可提供的，只能说所有的人来到这个世界上都有遗传基因，这些基因在某种程度上影响着他们的行为方式，所以一个国家人口的遗传构成应该对其结果有一些影响，这是合乎逻辑的。说到这里，我应该指出，我所看到的大多数证据表明，人口之间的行为变化中，只有一小部分（15% 或更少）可以用遗传差异来解释，所以相对于我提到的其他影响因素，遗传似乎是一个相对较小的决定因素。

HUMAN CAPITAL DETERMINANTS

人力资本的决定因素

●While the inherited assets and liabilities of a country are very important, history has shown that the way people are with themselves and others is the most important determinant. By that I mean whether they hold themselves to high standards of behavior, whether they are self-disciplined, and whether they are civil with others in order to be productive members of their societies is most important. These qualities plus flexibility and resilience (i.e., the capacity to adapt to both “bad” and “good” things) allows people to minimize setbacks and maximize opportunities. Character, common sense, creativity, and consideration in most people make for a productive society.

●虽然一个国家的继承资产和负债非常重要，但历史表明，人们与自己和他人相处的方式是最重要的决定因素。我的意思是，他们是否以高标准的行为要求自己，是否自律，以及是否与他人友好相处，以便成为社会中富有成效的成员，这一点最为重要。这些品质加上灵活性和复原力（即适应 “坏事” 和 “好事” 的能力）使人们能够最大限度地减少挫折，最大限度地利用机会。大多数人的性格、常识、创造力和考虑问题的能力使社会变得富有成效。

Because capital is an income-producing asset, human capital can be defined as a human who generates income.●When humans have the capacity to produce more revenue than they expend, there is good human capital and self-sufficiency. I call this “self-sufficient plus,” which is what all people, companies, and countries should strive for in order for them individually and collectively to be strong financially. The likelihood of having good human capital and being “self-sufficient plus” is improved through quality education, a culture of hard work and cooperation, training, etc. Societies that don’t have good human capital are either drawing down their resources or getting deeper into debt they won’t be able to pay back (i.e., they’re headed for trouble).

因为资本是一种产生收入的资产，人力资本可以被定义为产生收入的人。当人类有能力产生比他们的支出更多的收入时，就有了良好的人力资本和自给自足。我把这称为 “自给自足加”，这是所有的人、公司和国家应该争取的，以使他们个人和集体在财务上强大。拥有良好的人力资本和 “自给自足+” 的可能性通过高质量的教育、勤奋工作和合作的文化、培训等来提高。没有良好的人力资本的社会，要么是在消耗他们的资源，要么是在无力偿还的债务中越陷越深（也就是说，他们正在走向困境）。

●While many countries have natural resources that they are able to draw upon, human capital is the most sustainable capital because inherited assets that are drawn down eventually disappear, whereas human capital can exist forever.

●虽然许多国家有能够利用的自然资源，但人力资本是最可持续的资本，因为继承下来的资产被提取后最终会消失，而人力资本可以永远存在。

Human capital is why people who come up with new ideas and build them out (e.g., entrepreneurs) beat giants with vast resources (just look at Elon Musk and his startup Tesla, which rivals resource-rich General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler; or Steve Jobs and Bill Gates, whose computer startups surpassed giants like IBM; and so on). Great human capital allows people to overcome their weaknesses and identify and capitalize on their opportunities. It is the attribute that has allowed small countries like the Netherlands, England, Switzerland, and Singapore to achieve great wealth and (in some cases) power.

人力资本是那些提出新想法并将其打造出来的人（如企业家）击败拥有庞大资源的巨头的原因（只要看看埃隆·马斯克和他的创业公司特斯拉，它与资源丰富的通用汽车、福特和克莱斯勒相抗衡；或者史蒂夫·乔布斯和比尔·盖茨，他们的计算机创业公司超越了 IBM 等巨头；等等）。伟大的人力资本使人们能够克服自己的弱点，发现并利用自己的机会。它是使荷兰、英国、瑞士和新加坡等小国实现巨大财富和（在某些情况下）权力的属性。

THE MOST IMPORTANT HUMAN NATURE DETERMINANTS

最重要的人性决定因素

Across societies and throughout time, people share the same human nature, which makes them much more alike than different. People behave similarly when faced with similar circumstances, driving the Big Cycles.

在各个社会和整个时代，人们有着相同的人性，这使得他们的相似性远远大于差异性。人们在面对类似的环境时，会有类似的行为，推动大循环的发展。

5. Self-Interest. Self-interest, especially self-survival, is the most powerful motivator for most people, organizations, and governments. However, which self-interest—e.g., the individual’s, the family’s, the country’s, etc.—matters most is a critical determinant of the society’s success. See the addendum that follows this chapter to learn more.

5.5. 自我利益。自我利益，尤其是自我生存，是大多数人、组织和政府最强大的动力。然而，哪种自我利益 —— 例如，个人的、家庭的、国家的等等 —— 最重要，是社会成功的关键决定因素。请参阅本章后的附录，以了解更多信息。

6. The Drive to Gain and Keep Wealth and Power. The quest for wealth and power is a powerful motivator of individuals, families, companies, states, and countries, though that’s not totally true because different individuals, families, companies, states, and countries value wealth and power differently relative to other things. For some, wealth and power are not nearly as important as other things that life has to offer. But for most, especially those who become the most wealthy and powerful, the pursuit of wealth and power is all-consuming. To be successful over the long run, a country must earn an amount that is at least equal to what it spends. Those that earn and spend modestly and have a surplus are more sustainably successful than those that earn and spend a lot more and have deficits. History shows that when an individual, organization, country, or empire spends more than what it earns, misery and turbulence are ahead. For more, see the addendum.

6. 获得和保持财富和权力的动力。对财富和权力的追求是个人、家庭、公司、州和国家的强大动力，尽管这并不完全正确，因为不同的个人、家庭、公司、州和国家对财富和权力的重视程度与其他事物不同。对一些人来说，财富和权力还不如生活中的其他东西重要。但对大多数人来说，尤其是那些成为最富有和最有权势的人，对财富和权力的追求是全身心的。要想长期成功，一个国家的收入必须至少与它的支出相等。那些收入和支出适度且有盈余的国家，比那些收入和支出多且有赤字的国家更容易持续成功。历史表明，当一个人、组织、国家或帝国的支出超过其收入时，痛苦和动荡就会出现。更多内容请见附录。

7. Capital Markets. The ability to save and obtain buying power through one’s capital markets is essential to a country’s well-being. For that reason, how well they are developed is an important determinant of a country’s success.

7.7. 资本市场。通过一个国家的资本市场进行储蓄和获得购买力的能力对一个国家的福祉至关重要。因此，资本市场的发展程度是一个国家成功的重要决定因素。
