Europe was one world, Russia was another, and China and the areas around it were an even more remote world. States that in retrospect seem tiny and numerous did not seem that way at all at the time. Because national boundaries didn’t exist as they do today, there were almost constant fights with neighbors over wealth and power in their neighborhoods.

当时的世界要 “大” 得多。五百年前，人们可以在一天内骑马旅行大约 25 英里。今天，人们有可能在同样的时间内到达世界的另一端。阿波罗号宇航员往返月球的速度比 1500 年旅行者从巴黎到罗马的速度要快得多。因此，相关的地理区域 —— 例如，谁能影响谁 —— 要小得多，所以世界看起来大得多。欧洲是一个世界，俄罗斯是另一个世界，而中国和它周围的地区是一个更加遥远的世界。现在看来，那些小而多的国家在当时看来根本不是那么回事。因为当时没有像今天这样的国界线，所以几乎不断有邻居为争夺财富和权力而发生争吵。

But in 1500, that picture was changing quickly. The European powers were well into their Age of Exploration, which was led by the Portuguese and the Spanish and brought them into contact with faraway empires. Like all periods of great evolution, the Age of Exploration was enabled by technological developments that could make people rich—in this case, the invention of ships that could travel the world to accumulate riches by trading with and taking wealth from those who the explorers encountered. At the time, wealthy rulers funded the expeditions in exchange for a share of the bounty that the explorers brought back with them.

但在 1500 年，这种情况正在迅速改变。欧洲列强进入了他们的探索时代，由葡萄牙人和西班牙人领导，使他们与遥远的帝国建立了联系。像所有伟大的进化时期一样，探索时代是由能够使人们致富的技术发展促成的 —— 在这种情况下，船舶的发明可以在世界范围内旅行，通过与探险家遇到的人进行贸易并从他们那里获得财富来积累财富。当时，富有的统治者为探险队提供资金，以换取探险家带回来的赏金份额。

Countries Didn’t Exist—Instead, Territories Were Run by Families. Back in 1500, there were no sovereign states with borders and ruling orders. They hadn’t been invented yet. Instead there were big family estates called kingdoms and dynasties run by kings and emperors that almost constantly fought with their neighbors for wealth and power. When a kingdom conquered, grew, and encompassed enough area, it was called an empire. Because the ruling order was centered around families, kingdoms and dynasties at that time could inherit other lands if their rulers died and there was no closer relative, similar to how one would inherit property or a family company today. Arranged marriages were logical ways the empire could stay in the hands of a tighter family group rather than branching off and dissipating over the generations.

国家并不存在 —— 相反，领土是由家庭管理的。早在 1500 年，还不存在有边界和统治秩序的主权国家。它们还没有被发明出来。取而代之的是被称为王国和王朝的大型家族产业，由国王和皇帝管理，他们几乎一直在为财富和权力与邻国争斗。当一个王国征服、成长并涵盖了足够的面积时，它就被称为帝国。由于统治秩序是以家庭为中心的，当时的王国和王朝如果统治者去世，而又没有更近的亲属，就可以继承其他土地，类似于今天人们继承财产或家族公司的方式。包办婚姻是合乎逻辑的方式，帝国可以保持在一个更紧密的家族集团手中，而不是在几代人的时间里分化和消散。

Religions and Religious Leaders Were Much More Powerful—and Science as We Know It Today Didn’t Exist. In most of the world, the elites (i.e., that small percentage of the population who had most of the wealth and power) consisted of monarchs who supposedly gained their power from the divine, the clergy who represented the divine, and the landowning nobles who oversaw the peasants and largely treated them like oxen working the land. The monarchs had ministers, bureaucracies, and militaries that controlled and defended their territories for them.

宗教和宗教领袖的权力要大得多，而我们今天所知的科学并不存在。在世界大部分地区，精英（即拥有大部分财富和权力的一小部分人口）包括据称从神灵那里获得权力的君主，代表神灵的神职人员，以及监督农民的地主贵族，他们基本上把农民当作耕地的牛。君主们有大臣、官僚机构和军队，为他们控制和保卫他们的领土。

Though the Europeans and the Chinese were on opposite sides of the world and had virtually no contact with each other, they operated in essentially the same way, though China’s institutions were bigger, more developed, and less religious than Europe’s.

虽然欧洲人和中国人处于世界的两端，彼此几乎没有接触，但他们的运作方式基本相同，尽管中国的机构比欧洲的更大、更发达，而且宗教色彩更淡。

The World Was Much Less Egalitarian. The ideas that a) all people should be treated equally and b) judged by the law didn’t exist at the time. This was true both within kingdoms and between them; in both cases, power through arms and violence ruled the day. Up until the 1300s and 1400s, serfdom (i.e., peasants being essentially treated as the property of their rulers) existed in most of Western Europe, which meant that the only way for most people to assert their power was through revolt. While this had largely changed by 1500, the rights afforded to common people remained weak until the Enlightenment in the 1700s.

当时的世界没有那么多的平等主义。a）所有的人都应该被平等对待，b）受到法律的审判，这些想法在当时并不存在。在王国内部和王国之间都是如此；在这两种情况下，通过武器和暴力获得的权力统治着整个世界。直到 1300 年和 1400 年，西欧大部分地区都存在农奴制（即农民基本上被当作统治者的财产），这意味着大多数人维护其权力的唯一途径是通过叛乱。虽然这种情况在 1500 年时已基本改变，但在 17 世纪的启蒙运动之前，赋予普通人的权利仍然很薄弱。

THE WORLD’S EMPIRES IN 1500

1500 年的世界各帝国

Europe

欧洲

  • The Habsburg family dynasty controlled Spain and all the territories that Spain controlled plus a collection of territories that formed the Holy Roman Empire. This included parts of what we now call the Netherlands, Belgium, Italy, Germany, and Austria. It was the Western world’s most powerful empire.
  • 哈布斯堡家族王朝控制着西班牙和西班牙控制的所有领土，以及形成神圣罗马帝国的领土集合。这包括我们现在所说的荷兰、比利时、意大利、德国和奥地利的部分地区。它是西方世界最强大的帝国。
  • The Valois (later Bourbon) family dynasty, which was the main rival to the Habsburgs, controlled France. This led to a lot of fighting between the families.
  • 瓦卢斯（后来的波旁）家族王朝是哈布斯堡家族的主要对手，它控制着法国。这导致了家族之间的大量争斗。
  • The Tudor dynasty controlled England, which was not yet an important force in Europe though it was growing in strength.
  • 都铎王朝控制着英格兰，虽然它的实力在不断增强，但还不是欧洲的重要力量。
  • Florence, Venice, and Milan, which were frequently run as republics with prominent families, were where the action was. Most of the financial, commercial, intellectual, and artistic innovation coming out of Europe in 1500 originated in these states. They were very rich and played a central role in shaping Europe and the Western world at this time and for centuries to come because of the revolutionary ideas they fostered, ideas I will explore in more detail later.
  • 佛罗伦萨、威尼斯和米兰经常以共和国的形式运作，并拥有显赫的家族，它们是行动的场所。1500 年欧洲的大部分金融、商业、知识和艺术创新都源自于这些国家。它们非常富有，在当时和今后几个世纪里，在塑造欧洲和西方世界方面发挥了核心作用，因为它们培育了革命思想，这些思想我将在后面更详细地探讨。
  • The Papal States were run by the pope and the Catholic Church. Throughout Christian Europe, relationships between monarchs, nobles, and the church followed the typical formula of elites working in mutually supportive ways to drive the ruling orders to their benefit. As a result of this, the church acquired vast wealth, which it got mostly from poor peasants who gave money to the church (through the system of tithes) and worked without pay on church agricultural lands.
  • 教皇国是由教皇和天主教会管理的。在整个基督教欧洲，君主、贵族和教会之间的关系遵循典型的公式，即精英们以相互支持的方式工作，推动统治秩序为他们带来好处。这样做的结果是，教会获得了巨大的财富，这些财富主要来自于贫穷的农民，他们（通过什一税制度）向教会捐钱，并在教会的农田上无偿工作。
  • The Rurik dynasty, and later the Romanovs, ruled Russia, which was a peripheral power at the time and seemed remote to Europeans.
  • 鲁里克王朝以及后来的罗曼诺夫王朝统治着俄罗斯，当时的俄罗斯是一个外围大国，对欧洲人来说似乎很遥远。
  • The Ottoman Empire, named after its ruling family, was centered in Constantinople, which it had conquered in 1453.
  • 以其统治家族命名的奥斯曼帝国以君士坦丁堡为中心，于 1453 年征服了该城。

Additionally there were many hundreds, perhaps thousands, of family-run states across Europe. They fought all the time because each had to constantly defend and fight one’s neighbors. Allies and enemies were always important and constantly changing. This map shows the major powers in Europe in 1550. There were many more small states we couldn’t fit on this map.

此外，整个欧洲有数百个，也许是数千个家族经营的国家。他们一直在打仗，因为每个人都必须不断地保卫和打击自己的邻居。盟友和敌人总是很重要，而且不断变化。这张地图显示了 1550 年欧洲的主要国家。还有许多小国，我们无法在这张地图上找到。

Asia

亚洲

The Ming Dynasty controlled almost all of China and was the most advanced and powerful empire in the world. Like European empires, it was family-controlled with an emperor who had the “mandate of heaven.” The emperor oversaw a bureaucracy that was run and protected by ministers and military leaders who worked in symbiotic—though sometimes contentious—relationships with landowning noble families who oversaw peasant workers. In 1500 the Ming Dynasty was approaching its peak and was leaps and bounds ahead of Europe in wealth, technology, and power. It had enormous cultural and political influence all over East Asia and Japan. 1

明朝几乎控制了整个中国，是世界上最先进、最强大的帝国。与欧洲帝国一样，明朝是由家族控制的，皇帝拥有 “天命”。皇帝监督着一个官僚机构，该机构由大臣和军事领导人管理和保护，他们与监督农民工的地主贵族家庭保持着共生关系，尽管有时会发生争执。1500 年，明朝已接近其顶峰，在财富、技术和权力方面领先于欧洲。它在整个东亚和日本拥有巨大的文化和政治影响力。 1

At the time, Confucian scholars were then seen to be near the top of the social hierarchy, which helped them get ahead in politics. To get ahead one needed to study Confucianism in depth and pass highly competitive exams. Political decisions were frequently based on ruler’s interpretations of Confucian ideals. “Neo-Confucianism,” which was dominant at the time, shifted the focus of the belief system toward a more rational, philosophical, academic, and humanistic form. This way of thinking, which was practical, evidence-based, and scientific, was a key reason China pulled so far ahead of Europe in the Middle Ages. At the time, scholars and scientists had significant power, which led to remarkable technological advances (gun powder, the printing press, architecture, and more). Literacy rates were extremely high relative to other places at the time, and China was also advanced in medicine. For example, it had a widespread program of fighting smallpox infection via an early form of vaccination, centuries before Europe. Its financial system was relatively well developed with early forms of corporations and banks, a history of using (and misusing) printed money, and relatively sophisticated financial markets. And it was militarily very strong. The Ming Dynasty had the largest navy in the world and a standing army of a million troops.

在当时，儒家学者被视为接近社会等级制度的顶端，这有助于他们在政治上出人头地。为了出人头地，人们需要深入研究儒家思想，并通过竞争激烈的考试。政治决策往往是基于统治者对儒家理想的解释。当时占主导地位的 “新儒家” 将信仰体系的重点转向更加理性、哲学、学术和人文的形式。这种实用的、以证据为基础的、科学的思维方式，是中国在中世纪远远领先于欧洲的一个重要原因。当时，学者和科学家拥有巨大的权力，这导致了显著的技术进步（火药、印刷术、建筑等等）。相对于当时的其他地方，中国的识字率非常高，而且中国的医学也很先进。例如，它有一个广泛的计划，通过早期形式的疫苗接种来对抗天花感染，比欧洲早几个世纪。中国的金融系统相对发达，有早期的公司和银行形式，有使用（和滥用）印刷货币的历史，以及相对复杂的金融市场。它在军事上也非常强大。明朝拥有世界上最大的海军和一百万的常备军。

In his wonderful book, The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers, historian Paul Kennedy described it well:

历史学家保罗·肯尼迪在他的精彩著作《大国的兴衰》中对此作了很好的描述。

“Of all the civilizations of premodern times, none appeared more advanced, none felt more superior than that of China. Its considerable population, 100–130 million compared with Europe’s 50–55 million in the fifteenth century; its remarkable culture; its exceedingly fertile and irrigated plains, linked by a splendid canal system since the eleventh century; and its unified, hierarchic administration run by a well-educated Confucian bureaucracy had given a coherence and sophistication to Chinese society which was the envy of foreign visitors.”

“在前现代的所有文明中，没有哪种文明比中国更先进，没有哪种文明比中国更有优越感。它的人口众多，有 1 亿至 1.3 亿，而欧洲在 15 世纪只有 5000 万至 5500 万；它的文化杰出；它的平原极其肥沃，自 11 世纪以来就由一个辉煌的运河系统连接起来；它的统一、等级管理由受过良好教育的儒家官僚机构管理，使中国社会具有一致性和先进性，令外国游客羡慕不已。”

Ironically and typically, the enormity of the Ming Dynasty’s wealth and power is one possible explanation of what eventually led to its fall. Believing that they did not need anything else, the emperors put an end to China’s exploration of the world, closed its doors, and retired to lives of pleasure, and turned over the running of government to their ministers and eunuchs, which led to dysfunctional infighting, corruption, weakness, and vulnerability to attack. There was a shift away from pragmatic scientific study and innovation toward pedantic scholarship. As we’ll see in Chapter 12, this helped drive the decline of China relative to Europe.

具有讽刺意味的是，典型的是，明朝的巨大财富和权力是最终导致其衰落的一个可能解释。皇帝们认为他们不需要其他东西，因此结束了中国对世界的探索，关闭了国门，退休后过上了享乐的生活，并将政府的运作交给了他们的大臣和太监，这导致了功能紊乱的内讧、腐败、软弱和容易受到攻击。从务实的科学研究和创新向迂腐的学术研究转变。正如我们将在第 12 章看到的，这有助于推动中国相对于欧洲的衰落。

Across the rest of Asia, the story in 1500 was one of fragmentation. India was divided among several kingdoms, including the Delhi Sultanate in the north and the Hindu Vijayanagara Empire in the south. It was not an empire of note, though it was about to be, as in the 1520s the Mughal Empire began its conquest of India, eventually leading it to be among the world’s most powerful. Likewise Japan in 1500 was divided into many entities, experienced civil war, and was isolated, so it too was not a power of note.

在亚洲其他地区，1500 年的情况是四分五裂的。印度被几个王国瓜分，包括北部的德里苏丹国和南部的印度教维贾亚纳格拉帝国。它不是一个引人注目的帝国，尽管它即将成为一个帝国，因为在 15 世纪 20 年代，莫卧儿帝国开始征服印度，最终使其成为世界上最强大的帝国之一。同样，1500 年的日本也被分割成许多实体，经历了内战，并且被孤立，所以它也不是一个值得注意的大国。

The Middle East

中东地区

  • The Ottoman Empire, mentioned before, also came to control much of the Middle East by the mid-1500s, with a key rival in the new Safavid dynasty of Persia (modern-day Iran).
  • 前面提到的奥斯曼帝国也在 15 世纪中期控制了中东的大部分地区，其主要对手是波斯（今伊朗）的新萨法维王朝。

The Americas

美洲

  • The largest empires were the Aztec Empire centered in Mexico (its capital, Tenochtitlán, probably had a greater population than any city in Europe at the time) and the Incan Empire in South America. But soon the Europeans arrived, devastating both powers and leading to the emergence of new colonies, including the seedlings of what would become the United States 276 years later.
  • 最大的帝国是以墨西哥为中心的阿兹特克帝国（其首都特诺奇蒂特兰可能比当时欧洲任何城市的人口都多）和南美洲的印加帝国。但很快欧洲人到来，摧毁了这两个大国，并导致新殖民地的出现，包括 276 年后成为美国的幼苗。

Africa

非洲

  • A vast continent three times bigger than Europe was divided into dozens of kingdoms, often separated by large, sparsely populated areas. The biggest in the year 1500 was the Songhai Empire in West Africa, which had a reputation as a center of trade and Islamic scholarship.
  • 一个比欧洲大三倍的广袤大陆被划分为数十个王国，往往被大片人口稀少的地区隔开。1500 年，最大的王国是西非的桑海帝国，它以贸易和伊斯兰学术中心而闻名。

That was the lay of the land in 1500. The world order was about to change in very big ways.

这就是 1500 年的土地状况。世界秩序即将发生非常大的变化。

WHAT HAS HAPPENED SINCE 1500

1500 年以来发生了什么

As you might imagine, there are far too many important things that have happened since 1500 for me to fit into this tiny nutshell. However, I can hit the highlights of the story of how the world changed from 1500 until now, with an emphasis on the key themes and shifts I will be expanding on in the following chapters. The most important changes were the changes in thinking that led to people changing behaviors, particularly about how wealth and power should be shared. They were what made the story transpire as it did. It is easy to identify the biggest periods of change because they are generally called “revolutions” and “ages” (though sometimes they are called other things).

正如你可能想象的那样，自 1500 年以来发生的重要事情太多，我无法将其纳入这个小小的简讯中。然而，我可以打出从 1500 年至今世界如何变化的故事的要点，重点是我将在以下章节中展开的关键主题和转变。最重要的变化是导致人们改变行为的思维变化，特别是关于财富和权力应该如何分享的变化。它们是使故事发生的原因。识别最大的变化时期很容易，因为它们通常被称为 “革命” 和 “时代”（尽管有时它们被称为其他东西）。

When reading this short summary of the last 500 years, notice both the evolutions and the cycles. You will see that there were both 1) several revolutions in ways of thinking that led to tremendous evolution and progress over hundreds of years and 2) many cycles of peaceful and prosperous periods alternating with depressions and wars that marked the ends of old orders and beginnings of new ones.

当阅读这个关于过去 500 年的简短总结时，请注意演变和周期。你会看到，1）思维方式的几次革命导致了数百年来的巨大演变和进步；2）许多和平和繁荣时期的周期与标志着旧秩序结束和新秩序开始的萧条和战争交替出现。

The Commercial Revolution (1100s–1500s)

商业革命（1100 年代-1500 年代）

The Commercial Revolution was the move away from a solely agriculture-based economy to one that included trade in a variety of goods. This evolution began in the 12th century, and by 1500, it was centered in the Italian city-states due to a confluence of two factors that enabled them to become terrifically wealthy. First, the wars between Christian Europe and the Ottoman Empire significantly slowed land trade (especially for spices and luxuries) between Europe and the rest of the world, which created a significant opening for maritime trade. Second, a number of Italian city-states developed republican governments modeled after the Roman Republic. Their governments were more inventive and responsive than those in the rest of Europe, which allowed a strong merchant class to develop.

商业革命是指从单纯的农业经济转向包括各种商品贸易的经济。这一演变始于 12 世纪，到 1500 年，由于两个因素的汇合，它以意大利城邦为中心，使他们变得非常富有。首先，基督教欧洲和奥斯曼帝国之间的战争大大减缓了欧洲和世界其他地区之间的陆地贸易（特别是香料和奢侈品），这为海上贸易创造了一个重要的机会。其次，一些意大利城邦仿照罗马共和国的模式发展了共和制政府。他们的政府比欧洲其他地方的政府更有创造力和反应能力，这使得一个强大的商人阶层得以发展。

Venice was a prime example of this, as its governance system was designed with multiple checks and balances to ensure that there was a more meritocratic approach to government than existed in the rest of Europe. Venice’s leader—called the doge—did not have the right to name a successor and was restricted from bringing family members into government. New doges were chosen by vote by a series of committees whose members, in some cases, were chosen by lot from among several hundred aristocratic families. The Italians produced well-functioning capital markets, supported by new advances in bookkeeping and impartial institutions to enforce contracts. While private and government borrowing weren’t new, leading up to 1500, they tended to take place as bilateral deals between wealthy citizens, and defaults on creditors (or the expulsion and even execution of them) were extremely common. Because those who made money from trade—the merchant class—could benefit from a well-functioning financial system in which savings could be put into investments that fueled productivity, they created a number of financial innovations, including credit markets.

威尼斯是这方面的一个典型例子，因为其治理体系的设计具有多重制衡，以确保政府比欧洲其他地方有更多的任人唯贤的做法。威尼斯的领导人 —— 即教区长 —— 无权指定继任者，并被限制将家庭成员引入政府。新教区长由一系列委员会投票选出，这些委员会的成员在某些情况下是从几百个贵族家庭中抽签选出的。在簿记和执行合同的公正机构的新进展支持下，意大利人创造了运作良好的资本市场。虽然私人和政府借贷并不新鲜，但在 1500 年之前，它们往往是作为富裕公民之间的双边交易而发生的，债权人的违约（或驱逐甚至处决他们）是非常普遍的。因为那些从贸易中赚钱的人 —— 商人阶级 —— 可以从一个运作良好的金融系统中受益，在这个系统中，储蓄可以被投入到投资中，从而促进生产力，他们创造了许多金融创新，包括信贷市场。

With the proceeds from trade flowing in and a need for standardized coinage, coins minted in the Italian city-states, especially Florence’s gold florin, were of solid value, were well-recognized as such, and, as a result, began to be accepted as global currencies. On the basis of their solid currencies, these city-states developed effective lending and a publicly traded bond market. Venice established a perpetual bond early in the 12th century with a 5 percent coupon that the government would either issue (i.e., borrow) or purchase back depending on the finances/needs of the time. Venice’s merchants owned the bonds and had significant influence on the government, so default could only be a last resort. The centuries in which the bond existed without defaults gave lenders confidence in it and institutions for trading bonds in secondary markets made it a liquid form of investment.

随着贸易收益的流入和对标准化硬币的需求，意大利各城邦铸造的硬币，特别是佛罗伦萨的金弗罗林，具有坚实的价值，被公认为是坚实的，因此，开始被接受为全球货币。在其坚实的货币基础上，这些城邦发展了有效的借贷和公开交易的债券市场。威尼斯在 12 世纪初建立了一种永久债券，票面利率为 5%，政府会根据当时的财政/需求来发行（即借款）或回购。威尼斯的商人拥有这些债券，对政府有很大的影响力，所以违约只能是最后的手段。债券存在的几个世纪里没有违约，这让贷款人对它充满信心，而二级市场上的债券交易机构使它成为一种流动的投资形式。

The ability to borrow quickly at reasonable rates was an enormous boon to Venice. Though Venice eventually defaulted after losing a series of wars around 1500, liquid bond markets caught on elsewhere including in the Netherlands and in the UK.

以合理的利率迅速借款的能力对威尼斯来说是一个巨大的福音。尽管威尼斯在 1500 年左右输掉了一系列战争后最终违约，但流动的债券市场在其他地方，包括在荷兰和英国，都得到了发展。

The Renaissance (1300s–1600s)

文艺复兴（1300 年代-1600 年代）

A new way of thinking in many respects modeled after the ancient Greeks and Romans started in Italian city-states around 1300 and passed through Europe until the 1600s, in a period known as the Renaissance. Renaissance thinkers made a big pivot toward using logical reasoning instead of divine intention as the way to explain how the world works. This shift contributed to dizzyingly fast discoveries that led to artistic and technological advances in Europe. It began in the city-states of northern Italy where the Commercial Revolution had created riches that led to advances in trade, production, and banking enabled by intellectualism and creativity. The Renaissance was one of history’s greatest cases of a self-reinforcing cycle I described in Chapter 5: peaceful periods in which creativity and commerce reinforce each other to produce an economic boom and great advancements.

一种在许多方面仿效古希腊和古罗马人的新思维方式于 1300 年左右在意大利各城邦开始，并在欧洲传递，直到 16 世纪，在一个被称为文艺复兴的时期。文艺复兴时期的思想家们做出了一个重大的转变，即用逻辑推理而不是用神圣的意图来解释世界如何运作。这一转变促成了令人眼花缭乱的快速发现，导致了欧洲的艺术和技术进步。文艺复兴开始于意大利北部的城邦，那里的商业革命创造了财富，导致贸易、生产和银行业的进步，并由知识主义和创造力促成。文艺复兴是我在第五章中描述的历史上最伟大的自我强化循环的案例之一：在和平时期，创造力和商业相互强化，产生经济繁荣和巨大的进步。

In the middle of it, and propelling it forward, were people and families like the Medici, who were merchants and bankers, not feudal kings. They used their riches to support the arts, architecture, and science.2 Alongside the flourishing in art and architecture were huge advances in science, technology, and business. Knowledge and ideas spread rapidly because of the invention of the printing press in the mid-15th century.

在这中间，推动它前进的是像美第奇家族这样的人和家族，他们是商人和银行家，而不是封建国王。他们用自己的财富来支持艺术、建筑和科学。2伴随着艺术和建筑的蓬勃发展，科学、技术和商业也取得了巨大的进步。由于 15 世纪中期印刷术的发明，知识和思想迅速传播。

By the way, many of the European Renaissance innovations had already been in place in China for centuries because the Chinese discovered the key elements to produce it—e.g., the printing press, the scientific method, and the meritocratic placements of people in jobs—much earlier. One can think of China’s Neo-Confucianism, described earlier, as being like China’s Renaissance because, as in Europe’s Renaissance, it led to more logic- and evidence-based thinking and more inventive rather than religious worldviews.

顺便说一下，欧洲文艺复兴的许多创新在中国已经存在了几个世纪，因为中国人更早地发现了产生这些创新的关键因素 —— 例如，印刷术、科学方法和择优录取的工作安排。我们可以把前面描述的中国的新儒家思想看作是中国的文艺复兴，因为和欧洲的文艺复兴一样，它导致了更多基于逻辑和证据的思考，以及更多创造性而非宗教的世界观。

As the new ideas spread across Europe in the late 16th and early 17th centuries, luminaries such as Shakespeare and Francis Bacon in England, Descartes in France, and Erasmus in the Netherlands had broad impacts. Living standards rose dramatically, though much more for the elites than for peasants. In Italy, this period of relative peace and prosperity eventually led to excesses, decadence, and decline as the city-states became less competitive and their financial conditions deteriorated.

随着 16 世纪末和 17 世纪初新思想在欧洲的传播，英国的莎士比亚和弗朗西斯·培根、法国的笛卡尔和荷兰的伊拉斯谟等名人产生了广泛影响。生活水平急剧上升，尽管精英们的生活水平比农民高得多。在意大利，这段相对和平和繁荣的时期最终导致了过度、颓废和衰落，因为城邦的竞争力下降，财政状况恶化。

The Age of Exploration and Colonialism (1400s–1700s)

探索和殖民主义时代（14 世纪-17 世纪）

The Age of Exploration began in the 1400s when Europeans traveled all over the world in search of wealth, creating widespread contact between many different peoples for the first time and beginning to shrink the world. It roughly coincided with the Renaissance because the technological marvels of the Renaissance translated into advancements in shipbuilding and navigation, and the riches that those ships brought back financed further Renaissance advancements.

探险时代开始于 14 世纪，当时欧洲人为了寻找财富走遍了世界各地，第一次在许多不同的民族之间建立了广泛的联系，并开始缩小世界的范围。它与文艺复兴时期大致吻合，因为文艺复兴时期的技术奇迹转化为造船和航海方面的进步，而这些船只带回的财富为文艺复兴时期的进一步进步提供了资金。

Ruling families supported these money-making explorations and split the profits with explorers. For example, Henry the Navigator, the brother of the head of the Portuguese royal family, sponsored some of the earliest voyages and established a trading empire in Africa and Asia. Spain followed suit, swiftly conquering and colonizing significant portions of the Western Hemisphere, including the precious-metal-rich Aztec and Incan empires. Though Portugal and Spain were rivals, the unexplored world was huge, and when they had disputes, they were successfully mediated. Spain’s integration into the Habsburg Empire and its control over highly profitable silver mines made it stronger than Portugal in the 1500s, and for a roughly 60-year period starting in the late 1500s the Habsburg king ruled Portugal as well. Both translated their wealth into golden ages of art and technology. The Spanish Empire grew so large it became known as “the empire on which the sun never sets”—an expression that would later be used to describe the British Empire.

统治家族支持这些赚钱的探险活动，并与探险家分享利润。例如，葡萄牙王室首脑的兄弟航海家亨利赞助了一些最早的航行，并在非洲和亚洲建立了一个贸易帝国。西班牙紧随其后，迅速征服并殖民了西半球的大部分地区，包括富含贵金属的阿兹特克和印加帝国。虽然葡萄牙和西班牙是竞争对手，但未开发的世界是巨大的，当他们发生争端时，都能成功地进行调解。西班牙融入哈布斯堡帝国并控制着高利润的银矿，这使得它在 15 世纪比葡萄牙更强大，而且从 15 世纪末开始的大约 60 年时间里，哈布斯堡国王也统治着葡萄牙。两者都将其财富转化为艺术和技术的黄金时代。西班牙帝国发展得如此之大，被称为 “日不落帝国” —— 这个说法后来被用来描述大英帝国。

As European nations found ways to make their explorations more profitable, the rise of global trade transformed their economies. Most notably, the flow of new riches (particularly silver) to Europe fueled a rise in prices for basic goods and services. Referred to as the Spanish Price Revolution, Europe went from hundreds of years of steady prices to a doubling of prices every few decades, a reminder of how big shifts can have economic impacts that seem unimaginable based on one’s most recent experiences.

随着欧洲国家找到了使其探险活动更有利可图的方法，全球贸易的兴起改变了他们的经济。最值得注意的是，新的财富（尤其是白银）流入欧洲，推动了基本商品和服务价格的上涨。被称为 “西班牙价格革命”，欧洲从数百年的稳定价格变成了每隔几十年就翻一番的价格，这提醒我们，巨大的转变会对经济产生怎样的影响，而这种影响在一个人最近的经历中是无法想象的。

Eventually this push toward exploration led Europe to trade with—and exploit—Asia, most notably China, Japan, and the Indian subcontinent. The Portuguese were the first of these explorers to approach China in 1513, though other European explorers like Marco Polo had been in contact before. Europeans were dazzled by the quality of Chinese porcelain, silk, and other goods, which became highly sought after, but the Chinese weren’t interested in buying European goods, which they considered inferior. However they eagerly accepted silver, which was money in China as well as in Europe, as payment. As we’ll cover later, China struggled for centuries with shortages of the precious metals it needed to have a sufficient supply of money. However the Europeans didn’t have enough silver to trade and the Chinese weren’t interested in other goods, which eventually led to the Opium Wars and other interesting stories that we will explore later.

最终，这种探索的推动使欧洲开始与亚洲进行贸易和开发，最明显的是中国、日本和印度次大陆。葡萄牙人是这些探险家中第一个在 1513 年接近中国的人，尽管其他欧洲探险家如马可·波罗之前就有过接触。欧洲人对中国瓷器、丝绸和其他商品的质量感到眼花缭乱，这些商品变得非常抢手，但中国人对购买欧洲商品不感兴趣，他们认为这些商品低劣。然而，他们热衷于接受白银，这在中国和欧洲都是货币，作为付款。正如我们稍后将介绍的那样，中国几个世纪以来一直在与贵金属的短缺作斗争，它需要有足够的货币供应。然而，欧洲人没有足够的白银来交易，而中国人对其他商品不感兴趣，这最终导致了鸦片战争和其他有趣的故事，我们将在后面探讨。

China’s Ming Dynasty had its own version of the Age of Exploration but abandoned it. Starting in the early 1400s, Ming Dynasty Emperor Yongle empowered his most trusted admiral, Zheng He, to lead seven major naval expeditions—“treasure voyages”—around the world. Though not colonizing expeditions (and historians debate the extent to which they were commercial), these naval missions helped project China’s power abroad. Yongle’s navy was the largest and most sophisticated in the world, featuring larger and better-constructed ships than any country in Europe would produce for at least a century.

中国的明朝曾有过自己版本的探索时代，但却放弃了它。从 14 世纪初开始，明朝皇帝永乐授权他最信任的海军将领郑和率领七次大型海军远征 —— “寻宝之旅” —— 环游世界。虽然不是殖民远征（历史学家对其商业化程度也有争议），但这些海军任务有助于将中国的力量投射到国外。永乐的海军是世界上最大和最复杂的，其特点是比欧洲任何国家至少在一个世纪内生产的船只更大和更好。

China’s international influence, as indicated by the number of foreign cities engaged in formal tributary relationships with the mainland, increased rapidly. However, the Ming emperors chose to end these voyages and pulled the empire into itself. It remains a matter of conjecture whether that is because Yongle’s military and naval expeditions were expensive or because the emperors believed that they had all they needed within China so there was no need for this exploration.

中国的国际影响力，正如与大陆建立正式支流关系的外国城市数量所表明的那样，迅速增加。然而，明朝皇帝选择结束这些远航，将帝国拉入自己的行列。这仍然是一个猜测，是否因为永乐的军事和海军远征很昂贵，还是因为皇帝们认为他们在中国境内已经拥有了他们所需要的一切，所以没有必要进行这种探索。

The result of this pullback was an Age of Isolationism in China and in Japan as well, where it was called Sakoku. For the next several centuries, China and Japan broadly moved away, in fits and starts, from openness toward foreigners and toward distance and isolation.

这种回撤的结果是中国和日本的孤立主义时代，在日本被称为 “朔方”。在接下来的几个世纪里，中国和日本大体上都从对外国人的开放走向了距离和孤立。

The Reformation (1517–1648)

宗教改革（1517-1648）

Beginning in the 1500s in Europe, Protestant religious movements initiated a revolution against the Roman Catholic Church, which contributed to a series of wars and the bringing down of the then-existing European order. As previously explained, at the time, the existing order consisted of monarchs, nobles, and the church in symbiotic relationships. The Reformation took aim at the power and corruption of the Roman Catholic Church and sought an independent religion in which people dealt with God directly rather than one mediated by the church’s rules. At the time, many Catholic bishops and other senior clergy lived like princes in palaces and the church sold “indulgences” (a supposed reduction in time people would have to spend in purgatory). The Roman Catholic Church was a nation as much as it was a religion, directly governing a sizable share of modern Italy (the Papal States).

从 15 世纪的欧洲开始，新教宗教运动发起了一场反对罗马天主教会的革命，这促成了一系列的战争和当时存在的欧洲秩序的崩溃。如前所述，在当时，现有的秩序是由君主、贵族和教会组成的共生关系。宗教改革的目标是罗马天主教会的权力和腐败，并寻求一种独立的宗教，让人们直接与上帝打交道，而不是由教会的规则来调解。当时，许多天主教主教和其他高级神职人员像王子一样生活在宫殿里，教会出售 “赎罪券”（据说可以减少人们在炼狱中度过的时间）。罗马天主教会是一个国家，就像它是一个宗教一样，直接管理着现代意大利（教皇国）的相当大的一部分。

The Reformation started in 1517, when Martin Luther published his Ninety-Five Theses, challenging the papal monopoly on the interpretation of the Bible and on papal power in general. When he refused to recant his ideas, he was declared a heretic and excommunicated. His ideas—and those of other theologians—nonetheless took hold in large parts of Europe, thanks to the political support of key nobles, as well as the new printing press technology. That move, together with the usual constant fighting for power, broke down the existing European world order.

宗教改革开始于 1517 年，当时马丁·路德发表了他的《九十五条论纲》，挑战教皇对圣经解释的垄断和教皇的总体权力。当他拒绝收回他的想法时，他被宣布为异端并被逐出教会。然而，由于关键贵族的政治支持，以及新的印刷技术，他的思想和其他神学家的思想在欧洲大部分地区得到了认可。这一举措，再加上通常的不断争夺权力，打破了现有的欧洲世界秩序。

In virtually all the major Christian powers, the immediate impact of the Reformation was increased internal conflict and instability, and the instability extended between countries too. The Wars of Religion were intertwined with the wars against the existing orders and existing elites. They included an extended civil war in France in which an estimated 3 million people died and later contributed to an extended civil war in the UK. In the end, the Reformation led to Protestants earning substantial rights and freedoms. It also undermined the power of the Holy Roman Empire and the Habsburgs, left Germany with deep divisions that would continue to build through the end of the incredibly brutal Thirty Years’ War in the mid-1600s, and led to civil wars for over a hundred years. As is typical, the big war led to a new order, which was followed by a period of peace and prosperity.

在几乎所有的基督教大国中，宗教改革的直接影响是内部冲突和不稳定的增加，而且这种不稳定也在国家之间延伸。宗教战争与反对现有秩序和现有精英的战争交织在一起。这些战争包括法国的长期内战，估计有 300 万人死于其中，后来又促成了英国的长期内战。最后，宗教改革使新教徒获得了大量的权利和自由。它还削弱了神圣罗马帝国和哈布斯堡王朝的权力，给德国留下了深刻的分裂，这种分裂将持续到 16 世纪中期令人难以置信的残酷的三十年战争结束，并导致了长达一百多年的内战。如同典型的情况一样，大的战争导致了新的秩序，随之而来的是一段和平与繁荣的时期。

The New World Order Following the Thirty Years’ War (1648)

三十年战争（1648 年）后的世界新秩序

On its surface, the Thirty Years’ War pitted Protestant countries against Catholic ones; however, the full story was more complicated with wider geopolitical interests related to wealth and power playing a role of who lined up with whom. At the end of the war the new order was laid out at the Peace of Westphalia. The most important breakthroughs that came from it were the establishment of geographic borders and the sovereign rights of the people within those borders to decide what happens in their domains. Like most periods after major wars and the establishment of new orders, there was an extended time of peace between countries, with the Dutch emerging from the chaos as the leading global economic power. However, the battles for wealth and power—most importantly between declining monarchies and their subjects—continued across the continent.

从表面上看，三十年战争使新教国家与天主教国家对立起来；然而，整个故事更加复杂，与财富和权力有关的更广泛的地缘政治利益在谁与谁的关系中起了作用。战争结束后，新秩序在《威斯特伐利亚和约》中得到了确立。其中最重要的突破是确立了地理边界和边界内人民的主权权利，以决定在其领域内发生什么。像大多数重大战争和新秩序建立后的时期一样，国家之间有一段较长的和平时期，荷兰从混乱中脱颖而出，成为全球领先的经济大国。然而，对财富和权力的争夺 —— 最重要的是衰落的君主和他们的臣民之间的争夺 —— 在整个欧洲大陆持续不断。

The Invention of Capitalism (1600s)

资本主义的发明（16 世纪）

Beginning with the Dutch, the development of publicly available and popularly used equity markets allowed savers to effectively transfer their buying power to entrepreneurs who could put that buying power to productive and profitable use. This significantly improved the allocation of resources and was stimulative to economies because it produced new buying power. It also produced the capital markets cycles. While there were many elements involved in the creation of capitalism, a series of related economic and financial developments—most notably the developments of publicly traded stock and bond markets such as the opening of the Amsterdam Stock Exchange in 1602 and the Bank of England’s first government bond issuance (to fund the war with France) in 1694—are associated with it. Along with the advances of the Scientific Revolution, the invention of capitalism was a key reason behind the shift from slow real GDP growth to the faster growth, as seen in the chart I showed in Chapter 1. We will explore this innovation and its tremendous impact in more detail in the following chapter.

从荷兰人开始，公开的和普遍使用的股票市场的发展使储蓄者能够有效地将他们的购买力转移给企业家，而企业家可以将这种购买力用于生产和盈利。这大大改善了资源的配置，并刺激了经济，因为它产生了新的购买力。它还产生了资本市场周期。虽然有许多因素参与了资本主义的创造，但一系列相关的经济和金融发展 —— 最值得注意的是公开交易的股票和债券市场的发展，如 1602 年阿姆斯特丹证券交易所的开业和 1694 年英格兰银行的第一次政府债券发行（为与法国的战争提供资金） —— 都与之有关。与科学革命的进步一起，资本主义的发明是实际 GDP 增长缓慢转向较快增长的关键原因，正如我在第一章展示的图表中所看到的。我们将在下一章中更详细地探讨这一创新及其巨大的影响。

The Scientific Revolution (1500s–1600s)

科学革命（15 世纪-16 世纪）

The Scientific Revolution was an extension of the Renaissance-era shift from finding truth in religion to finding truth in logical reasoning and the Reformation’s drive to question authority and think for oneself. These factors led to the development of the scientific method, which improved humanity’s understanding of the world, establishing protocols by which scientific discoveries could be investigated and proven and ushering in many discoveries that raised living standards.

科学革命是文艺复兴时期从宗教中寻找真理到从逻辑推理中寻找真理的转变，以及宗教改革对质疑权威和自我思考的推动的延伸。这些因素导致了科学方法的发展，提高了人类对世界的认识，建立了可以调查和证明科学发现的协议，并迎来了许多提高生活水平的发现。

The scientific method was pioneered by Francis Bacon in the early 1600s, though many important advances in astronomy—particularly the work of Copernicus and Galileo—took place earlier, in the 1500s. These discoveries vastly expanded European knowledge about the solar system for the first time since the Greco-Roman period and were paralleled by many others across anatomy, mathematics, physics (e.g., Isaac Newton’s laws of motion), and many other fields. European governments began to support and sponsor this research, with the most famous example being the Royal Society in the UK, which was founded in 1660 and proved instrumental in promoting the exchange of ideas and discoveries (Newton was its president from 1703 to 1727). Over the centuries to come, the discoveries of the Scientific Revolution helped unleash economic growth and greater competitiveness for the major European powers, particularly the UK. The ideas and methods that underpinned the revolution were applied to more and more fields through the movement known as the Enlightenment.

科学方法是弗朗西斯·培根在 16 世纪初开创的，尽管天文学的许多重要进展 —— 特别是哥白尼和伽利略的工作 —— 发生在更早的 15 世纪。这些发现极大地扩展了欧洲人自希腊罗马时期以来对太阳系的认识，并在解剖学、数学、物理学（如艾萨克·牛顿的运动定律）和许多其他领域取得了同样的发现。欧洲各国政府开始支持和赞助这项研究，最著名的例子是英国的皇家学会，该学会成立于 1660 年，被证明在促进思想和发现的交流方面发挥了作用（牛顿在 1703 年至 1727 年期间担任该学会会长）。在接下来的几个世纪里，科学革命的发现帮助欧洲主要大国，特别是英国，实现了经济增长，提高了竞争力。通过被称为启蒙运动的运动，支撑这场革命的思想和方法被应用到越来越多的领域。

The First Industrial Revolution (1700s–1800s)

第一次工业革命（1700 年代-1800 年代）

Beginning in the UK in the 1700s, freeing people to be inventive and productive and providing them with capital led many societies to shift to new machine-based manufacturing processes, creating the first sustained and widespread period of productivity improvement in thousands of years. These improvements began with agricultural inventions that increased productivity, which led to a population boom and a secular shift toward urbanization as the labor intensity of farming declined. As people flocked to cities, industry benefited from the steadily increasing supply of labor, creating a virtuous cycle and leading to shifts in wealth and power both within and between nations. The new urban populations needed new types of goods and services, which required the government to get bigger and spend money on things like housing, sanitation, and education, as well as on the infrastructure for the new industrial capitalist system, such as courts, regulators, and central banks. Power moved into the hands of central government bureaucrats and the capitalists who controlled the means of production.

从 17 世纪的英国开始，解放人们的创造力和生产力，并为他们提供资本，使许多社会转向以机器为基础的新的制造工艺，创造了几千年来第一个持续和广泛的生产力改进时期。这些改进始于提高生产力的农业发明，随着农业劳动强度的下降，导致了人口激增和向城市化的长期转变。随着人们涌入城市，工业从稳定增长的劳动力供应中获益，形成了一个良性循环，导致国家内部和国家之间的财富和权力转移。新的城市人口需要新类型的商品和服务，这就要求政府变得更大，把钱花在住房、卫生和教育等方面，以及新的工业资本主义体系的基础设施上，如法院、监管机构和中央银行。权力转移到中央政府的官僚和控制生产资料的资本家手中。

Geopolitically, these developments most helped the UK, which pioneered many of the most important innovations. The UK caught up to the Netherlands in output per capita around 1800, before overtaking them in the mid-19th century, when the British Empire approached its peak share of world output (around 20 percent).

在地缘政治上，这些发展对英国的帮助最大，它开创了许多最重要的创新。英国在 1800 年左右在人均产出方面赶上了荷兰，然后在 19 世纪中期超过了他们，当时大英帝国在世界产出中的份额接近高峰（约 20%）。

The Enlightenment and the Age of Revolutions (1600s–1700s)

启蒙运动和革命时代（16 世纪-17 世纪）

Also known as the Age of Reason, the Enlightenment was essentially the scientific method applied to how humans should behave. This way of thinking became widespread in Europe in the 1700s and 1800s and was an extension of the diminishing of the rights of the monarchy and the church and the increasing of the rights of the individual that characterized earlier intellectual movements. New fields like economics expanded thanks to thinkers like Adam Smith, while figures like John Locke and Montesquieu pushed political philosophy in new directions. In particular, the Enlightenment ideas of these and other figures promoted rationality and individual liberties and undermined monarchic and religious powers, creating a movement toward overthrowing monarchies known as the Age of Revolutions. This wave of revolutions included the American, French, Spanish, German, Portuguese, and Italian. As is typical, this era of upheaval led some nations to seek out strong leaders who could bring order to the chaos. In the case of France, that leader was Napoleon, who changed the course not just of French history but of European history as he sought to conquer all of Europe. Napoleon was the classic great benevolent dictator who converted chaos into order and prosperity, and expanded the empire with his military prowess. As is often the case, he overreached and failed.

启蒙运动也被称为 “理性时代”，基本上是将科学方法应用于人类应该如何行事。这种思维方式在 17 世纪和 19 世纪的欧洲广为流传，是早期知识运动中君主和教会权利的减少和个人权利的增加的延伸。由于亚当·斯密这样的思想家，经济学等新领域得到了扩展，而约翰·洛克和孟德斯鸠等人则将政治哲学推向了新的方向。特别是，这些人和其他人物的启蒙思想促进了理性和个人自由，削弱了君主和宗教权力，创造了一个被称为革命时代的推翻君主的运动。这一革命浪潮包括美国、法国、西班牙、德国、葡萄牙和意大利的革命。典型的情况是，这个动荡的时代导致一些国家寻找能够在混乱中带来秩序的强大领导人。就法国而言，这个领导人就是拿破仑，他不仅改变了法国历史的进程，而且改变了欧洲历史的进程，因为他试图征服整个欧洲。拿破仑是典型的伟大仁慈的独裁者，他将混乱转化为秩序和繁荣，并以其军事才能扩大帝国。如同通常的情况一样，他过度扩张并失败了。

The Napoleonic Wars and the New World Order that Followed (1803–1815)

拿破仑战争和随后的世界新秩序（1803-1815）。

The Napoleonic Wars lasted from 1803 to 1815, when Great Britain and its allies defeated Napoleon and his allies. As is usual, the victors got together to create a new world order, which was hashed out at the Congress of Vienna. It drew new boundaries to ensure that no European power would become too dominant, based on balance of power concepts that would avoid war. The British emerged as the world’s leading empire, and as is typical after the war and the establishment of a new order, there was an extended period of peace and prosperity—the Pax Britannica.

拿破仑战争从 1803 年持续到 1815 年，当时英国及其盟友打败了拿破仑及其盟友。像往常一样，胜利者聚集在一起建立了一个新的世界秩序，并在维也纳会议上达成了共识。它划定了新的边界，以确保没有一个欧洲大国会在避免战争的权力平衡概念基础上变得过于强大。英国成为世界上领先的帝国，在战争和新秩序建立后，典型的情况是出现了一个长期的和平与繁荣时期 —— 大英帝国。

Western Powers Move into Asia (1800S )

西方国家进入亚洲（1800S）

The British and other Western powers brought their gunboats to India, China, and Japan in the mid-1700s and into the 1800s, causing dramatic disruptions to the course of their histories. At the time, both China and Japan were isolationist. India was controlled by the Mughal Empire, which had expanded into a significant power in South Asia but experienced rapid decline in the 1700s. The Western powers, which were significantly more advanced militarily at this time, wanted to force trade on all three. The Chinese attempted to fight the British but lost; the Japanese saw this and opened themselves for trade after US Commander Matthew Perry sailed four warships into Tokyo Bay in 1853. These developments led to the eventual fall of the Qing Dynasty, the resignation of the Japanese government, and the continued control of India by the British. Especially in Japan and China, it also led to the realization that they needed to modernize, which prompted the Meiji Restoration (in Japan) and the Self-Strengthening Movement (in China). This move was very successful in Japan and not successful in China, which continued to suffer in what the Chinese call the Century of Humiliation.

英国和其他西方列强在 17 世纪中期和 19 世纪将他们的炮舰带到了印度、中国和日本，对它们的历史进程造成了巨大的干扰。当时，中国和日本都是孤立主义国家。印度由莫卧儿帝国控制，莫卧儿帝国在南亚已经扩展为一个重要的大国，但在 1700 年代经历了迅速的衰落。此时，军事上明显更先进的西方列强想对这三个国家强行进行贸易。中国人试图与英国人作战，但却输了；日本人看到了这一点，在美国指挥官马修·佩里于 1853 年将四艘军舰驶入东京湾后，他们开放了贸易。这些发展导致了清朝的最终倒台，日本政府的辞职，以及英国对印度的持续控制。特别是在日本和中国，这也导致了他们意识到需要现代化，这促使了明治维新（在日本）和自强运动（在中国）的发生。此举在日本非常成功，而在中国则不成功，中国继续遭受着中国人所说的屈辱世纪。

Second Industrial Revolution (1850s–early 1900s)

第二次工业革命（1850 年代-1900 年代初）

Beginning in the mid-1800s, a second big wave of innovation took place, centered at first around steam-powered locomotion (e.g., railroads) and then electricity, telephones, interchangeable manufacturing parts, and other innovations at the turn of the 20th century. Whereas the First Industrial Revolution was centered on the UK, the Second Industrial Revolution primarily benefited the United States. As is typical, this period produced both great wealth and great wealth gaps and excesses in the capital markets, leading to an era known as the Gilded Age in the US.

从 19 世纪中期开始，发生了第二次大的创新浪潮，起初以蒸汽动力机车（如铁路）为中心，然后是电力、电话、可互换的制造部件，以及 20 世纪初的其他创新。第一次工业革命以英国为中心，而第二次工业革命主要使美国受益。作为典型，这一时期既产生了巨大的财富，也产生了巨大的财富差距和资本市场的过度，导致美国出现了一个被称为 “镀金时代” 的时代。

Invention of Communism (1848)

共产主义的发明（1848 年）

The invention and development of communism in the mid-1800s came as a reaction against both capitalism and the wealth gaps it created and the benefits of the Industrial Revolutions going more to the owners of the new technologies than to the workers. Conflicts between communists and the established powers intensified around the turn of the century and led to a number of major revolutions in the 20th century, including in both Russia and China where communist governments took power.

19 世纪中期，共产主义的发明和发展是对资本主义及其造成的贫富差距以及工业革命的利益更多地落在新技术的所有者而不是工人身上的反应。在世纪之交，共产主义者和既有势力之间的冲突加剧，并导致了 20 世纪的一些重大革命，包括在俄罗斯和中国的共产主义政府掌权。

That brings us to the 20th century, which had two big cycles of boom, busts, wars, and new orders, the second of which we appear to be in the late stages of. Because I review these comprehensively in Chapters 10 through 13, and because they are much more familiar to most readers, I will end this overview here and dive now into the story of the Dutch and how they rose to become the first global reserve currency empire.

这把我们带到了 20 世纪，它有两个大的繁荣、萧条、战争和新秩序的周期，其中第二个周期我们似乎处于后期阶段。因为我在第 10 章至第 13 章中全面回顾了这些情况，也因为大多数读者对这些情况更为熟悉，所以我将在此结束这一概述，现在深入探讨荷兰的故事，以及他们如何崛起成为第一个全球储备货币帝国。

1 By the way, the existence of familial relationships in a Chinese dynasty should not be mistaken for loving and caring relationships, as, just like in Europe, fights between family members for control of dynasties were brutal and often to the death.

1顺便说一下，中国王朝中的家族关系的存在不应该被误认为是爱与关怀的关系，因为就像在欧洲一样，家族成员之间为控制王朝而进行的争斗是很残酷的，而且往往会导致死亡。

2 The Medici family, who ruled and developed Florence during the period (though Florence technically remained a republic for much of their rule), acquired their wealth and power as business leaders and bankers. The Medici used their wealth, power, and smarts to acquire more wealth and power and to contribute enormously to the arts and sciences. They also acquired significant political power in Europe. For example, to gain power and/or to provide public service, four popes came from the Medici family during their reign. A number of Medici were themselves artists and political leaders who looked to help not only the rich but also the middle and poorer classes in the city. However, like many multigenerational families and monarchies, after a few generations a weak head of the family and leader of the state, together with perceived excesses at a time of economic stress, led to a revolution. The Medici lost control of Florence on several occasions. While the Medici returned to power over the subsequent three centuries and the Renaissance continued, they struggled and failed in the mid-16th century as a result of wars, changing trade routes, and bad loan making, which damaged their finances, and of changes in social norms and political practices.

2在这一时期统治和发展佛罗伦萨的美第奇家族（尽管在他们统治的大部分时间里，佛罗伦萨在技术上仍然是一个共和国），作为商业领袖和银行家获得了他们的财富和权力。美第奇家族利用他们的财富、权力和智慧获得了更多的财富和权力，并对艺术和科学做出了巨大的贡献。他们还在欧洲获得了重要的政治权力。例如，为了获得权力和/或提供公共服务，四位教皇在位期间来自美第奇家族。一些美第奇家族的人本身就是艺术家和政治领袖，他们不仅希望帮助富人，也希望帮助城市中的中产阶级和穷人。然而，就像许多多代同堂的家族和君主一样，几代人之后，一个软弱的家族首领和国家领导人，加上在经济紧张时期被认为的过度行为，导致了一场革命。美第奇家族多次失去对佛罗伦萨的控制。虽然美第奇家族在随后的三个世纪里重新掌权，文艺复兴也在继续，但由于战争、贸易路线的改变、不良贷款等因素破坏了他们的财政，以及社会规范和政治实践的变化，他们在 16 世纪中期陷入了挣扎并失败。

CHAPTER 9 THE BIG CYCLE RISE AND DECLINE OF THE DUTCH EMPIRE AND THE GUILDER

第9章荷兰帝国和荷兰盾的大周期兴衰

A fter a series of attempted revolts in the mid-1500s, the Dutch, who were under the control of Habsburg Spain, finally became powerful enough to gain de facto independence in 1581. From 1625 until their collapse in 1795, the Dutch gained enough wealth and power to eclipse both the Habsburgs and China as the world’s richest empire.

A 经过 15 世纪中期的一系列起义尝试，受西班牙哈布斯堡控制的荷兰人终于变得足够强大，于 1581 年获得事实上的独立。从 1625 年到 1795 年的崩溃，荷兰人获得了足够的财富和权力，使哈布斯堡王朝和中国都黯然失色，成为世界上最富有的帝国。

The Dutch Empire rose for all the classic reasons explained in earlier chapters, peaking around 1650 in what is now remembered as the Dutch Golden Age. While its small population and territorial footprint prevented it from being the dominant military power on the European continent, it more than made up for that through a combination of economic strength, financial sophistication, and a strong navy that could protect its large empire of trading posts and colonies around the world. This allowed its currency, the Dutch guilder, to emerge as the first global reserve currency.

荷兰帝国的崛起有着前面几章所解释的所有经典原因，在 1650 年左右达到顶峰，也就是现在人们所记得的荷兰黄金时代。虽然它的人口和领土面积小，使它无法成为欧洲大陆上的主导军事力量，但它通过经济实力、金融成熟度和强大的海军来弥补这一缺陷，从而保护其在世界各地的贸易站和殖民地的庞大帝国。这使其货币荷兰盾成为第一个全球储备货币。

The following chart shows the eight powers that fueled the Dutch ascent and eventual decline.

下图显示了为荷兰的崛起和最终衰落推波助澜的八大力量。

What the chart doesn’t show is the decline of the prior leading power, the Habsburg Empire, which you can see in the next chart depicting the entire arc of the Dutch Empire with key events noted. The numbers mark the approximate times of the six stages of the internal order cycle.

这张图没有显示的是之前的领导大国哈布斯堡帝国的衰落，你可以在下一张描绘了荷兰帝国整个弧线的图表中看到，并注明了关键事件。这些数字标志着内部秩序周期的六个阶段的大致时间。

The story begins with the decline of the Spanish Habsburgs, which initiated the first stage of the Dutch Big Cycle.

故事开始于西班牙哈布斯堡王朝的衰落，它启动了荷兰大循环的第一阶段。

The Transition from the Spanish/Habsburg Empire to the Dutch Empire

从西班牙/哈布斯堡帝国到荷兰帝国的过渡

New empires rise when old ones become weak and decadent. The story of the Dutch Empire began when the Habsburg Empire became weak, decadent, and overextended in all the classic ways.

当旧的帝国变得虚弱和颓废时，新的帝国就会崛起。荷兰帝国的故事始于哈布斯堡帝国变得虚弱、颓废，并在所有经典的方面过度扩张的时候。

From 1519 until 1556, the Holy Roman emperor and head of the Habsburg Empire was Charles V. The union of territories he controlled—which included most of modern-day Netherlands, Belgium, Italy, Germany, Austria, and Spain—made the Habsburg Empire the most powerful family empire in Europe. Spain was especially strong 1 because of the wealth and power it acquired in the Age of Exploration. The Spanish fleet was clearly the most powerful navy in Europe. Spanish silver coinage came close to being a reserve currency—it was used as far afield as China. Things began to change around the mid-1500s as the seeds of decline that were planted in the top phase began to germinate and a revolutionary shift in power began to brew.

从 1519 年到 1556 年，神圣罗马帝国的皇帝和哈布斯堡帝国的首脑是查理五世。他控制的领土联盟 —— 包括现代荷兰、比利时、意大利、德国、奥地利和西班牙的大部分地区，使哈布斯堡帝国成为欧洲最强大的家族帝国。西班牙特别强大 1 因为它在探险时代获得了财富和权力。西班牙舰队显然是欧洲最强大的海军。西班牙的银币几乎成了储备货币 —— 它被用于远在中国的地方。事情在 15 世纪中期左右开始发生变化，因为在顶层阶段播下的衰落种子开始发芽，一场革命性的权力转移开始酝酿。

The decline of the Habsburgs happened in many of the classic ways. There were revolutions against the elites who held wealth and power by those without them, challenging the existing order. For example, as I explained in the previous chapter, new religious ideas surfaced in the form of the Reformation, a revolution against the Roman Catholic Church, which was perceived as decadent and exploitative. At the time, the Catholic Church and the Holy Roman Empire were a rich and powerful political force that was integral to the existing order. The revolution started when a collection of religious opposition groups known generally as Protestantism challenged the system. Martin Luther published his Ninety-Five Theses in 1517, challenging the papal interpretation of the Bible and papal power in general. When Luther refused to recant, he was declared a heretic and excommunicated. His ideas nonetheless took hold in large parts of Europe, thanks to the political support of key nobles, as well as Europe’s new printing press technology.

哈布斯堡王朝的衰落以许多经典的方式发生。那些没有财富和权力的精英们发生了革命，对现有秩序提出了挑战。例如，正如我在上一章中解释的那样，新的宗教思想以宗教改革的形式浮出水面，这是一场反对罗马天主教会的革命，罗马天主教会被认为是腐朽和剥削的。当时，天主教会和神圣罗马帝国是一种富有和强大的政治力量，是现有秩序的组成部分。革命开始于一个一般被称为新教的宗教反对派团体的集合，他们对这个体系提出了挑战。马丁·路德在 1517 年发表了他的《九十五条论纲》，挑战教皇对《圣经》的解释和教皇的总体权力。当路德拒绝悔改时，他被宣布为异端并被逐出教会。然而，由于关键贵族的政治支持，以及欧洲新的印刷技术，他的思想在欧洲大部分地区得到了认可。

This came at an economically difficult time, when conflicts were intensifying, leading to instability and terrible civil wars, 2 eventually culminating in the brutal Thirty Years’ War in the mid-1600s. Its biggest negative impact was on the Holy Roman Empire and the Habsburgs.

当时正值经济困难时期，冲突加剧，导致了不稳定和可怕的内战。 2 最终在 16 世纪中期的残酷的三十年战争中达到高潮。其最大的负面影响是对神圣罗马帝国和哈布斯堡王朝的影响。

Charles V failed to prevent the revolutionary impacts of the Reformation and with it the damage to the existing order. He was forced to sign the Peace of Augsburg in 1555, which weakened the Holy Roman Empire and the Habsburg dynasty. He abdicated and divided his holdings in two: the Holy Roman Empire, which he passed to his brother Ferdinand, and most of the rest of the Habsburg Empire—most importantly Spain, but also the Netherlands, Belgium, significant portions of Italy, and Spanish colonies abroad—which he passed on to his son Philip II. From that point forward, the decline followed the classic script:

查理五世没能阻止宗教改革的革命性影响，以及随之而来的对现有秩序的破坏。他被迫在 1555 年签署了《奥格斯堡和约》，这削弱了神圣罗马帝国和哈布斯堡王朝的实力。他退位并将他的财产一分为二：神圣罗马帝国，他将其传给了他的兄弟费迪南，而哈布斯堡帝国的其余大部分 —— 最重要的是西班牙，但也包括荷兰、比利时、意大利的重要部分和西班牙的海外殖民地，他将其传给了他的儿子菲利普二世。从那时起，帝国的衰落就遵循了经典的剧本。

  • The empire was overextended militarily. Not only did Spain face a lengthy revolt against its unpopular rule in the Netherlands, it also fought with the Ottoman Empire, various Italian states, the French, and the British. These wars were costly and chipped away at the Habsburg family dynasty even before the Thirty Years’ War.
  • 帝国在军事上被过度扩张了。西班牙不仅面临着反对其在荷兰不受欢迎的统治的长期叛乱，而且还与奥斯曼帝国、意大利各州、法国和英国交战。这些战争耗资巨大，甚至在三十年战争之前就已经侵蚀了哈布斯堡家族的王朝。
  • Terrible national finances caused the classic toxic mix of increased taxation, money printing, and rising debt. Philip II defaulted on debts four times during his reign.
  • 可怕的国家财政造成了典型的有毒混合物，即增加税收、印钞和增加债务。腓力二世在位期间曾四次拖欠债务。
  • The lower and middle classes suffered from rising food prices, which were increasing at an unprecedented rate from the Spanish Price Revolution.
  • 中下层阶级饱受食品价格上涨之苦，西班牙价格革命使食品价格以空前的速度增长。
  • Internal conflict grew, for all the previously mentioned reasons.
  • 由于前面提到的所有原因，内部冲突越来越多。
  • Leadership deteriorated. Philip II and his son Philip III preferred lavish living to governing and ultimately used money printing to cover the large deficits, which led to high inflation and economic pain. Those around them behaved similarly.
  • 领导力恶化了。腓力二世和他的儿子腓力三世更喜欢奢侈的生活，而不是执政，最终用印钞机来填补大量赤字，这导致了高通货膨胀和经济痛苦。他们周围的人也有类似的行为。

This chart shows the value of the most popular commonly circulating coin in silver terms. Adding cheap base metals to the monetary supply was the popular way to “print” and devalue money at the time. You can see it started in the early 1600s.

这个图表显示了最受欢迎的普通流通硬币以白银计算的价值。将廉价的基本金属添加到货币供应中是当时流行的 “印刷” 和货币贬值的方式。你可以看到它开始于 16 世纪初。

The events of the 1500s were not the end of the Habsburg Empire, nor even to its claim to control the Netherlands—that wouldn’t happen until the end of the Thirty Years’ War in 1648. But they did create the conditions that allowed the Dutch to rise.

15 世纪的事件并不是哈布斯堡帝国的终结，甚至也不是它对荷兰的控制权的终结 —— 这要到 1648 年三十年战争结束时才会发生。但它们确实创造了让荷兰人崛起的条件。

THE RISE

崛起

From 1581 until around 1625, the Dutch Empire was built following the classic steps of a rising empire outlined in Chapter 1. More specifically:

从 1581 年到 1625 年左右，荷兰帝国是按照第一章中概述的帝国崛起的经典步骤建立的。更具体地说。

  • Led by William the Silent, the Dutch successfully revolted against Spain in the Eighty Years’ War, which resulted in the Dutch Republic asserting its independence in 1581. William, who was basically the father of the Netherlands, was a skilled military commander and united the various Dutch provinces against the Spanish.
  • 在 “沉默的威廉” 的领导下，荷兰人在八十年战争中成功地反抗了西班牙，从而使荷兰共和国在 1581 年宣称自己独立。威廉基本上是荷兰之父，他是一位熟练的军事指挥官，并联合荷兰各省对抗西班牙。
  • While the Spanish and the Dutch continued to fight over the subsequent decades, the Dutch were able to gain independence and the seeds were sown for the rise of a more unified Dutch Republic (particularly as Philip II cut off trade with the Dutch, forcing them to expand abroad on their own).
  • 虽然西班牙人和荷兰人在随后的几十年里继续争斗，但荷兰人还是获得了独立，为一个更加统一的荷兰共和国的崛起播下了种子（特别是由于腓力二世切断了与荷兰人的贸易，迫使他们自己向国外扩张）。
  • Because the republic was set up to allow each of the underlying provinces to maintain a high degree of sovereignty, the rise of the Dutch Empire was driven by a collective of statesmen rather than by a single monarch or leader. Though nobles held the most important roles, this system created checks and balances and a partnership that proved effective.
  • 由于共和国的建立是为了让每个基础省份保持高度的主权，荷兰帝国的崛起是由一个政治家集体而不是由一个君主或领导人推动的。虽然贵族们担任着最重要的角色，但这种制度创造了制衡和伙伴关系，并被证明是有效的。
  • Dutch values and culture emphasized education, saving, merit, and tolerance.
  • 荷兰的价值观和文化强调教育、储蓄、功绩和宽容。
  • The break from Spain allowed the Dutch to create a more open and inventive society.
  • 与西班牙的决裂使荷兰人能够创造一个更加开放和富有创造力的社会。
  • The Dutch invented ships that could go around the world to collect riches, capitalism that could finance these and other productive endeavors, and many more breakthroughs that made them rich and powerful. The Dutch created the world’s first mega-corporation, the Dutch East India Company, which accounted for about one-third of world trade. 3 Dutch openness to new ideas, people, and technology helped them rise quickly.
  • 荷兰人发明了可以环游世界收集财富的船只，可以为这些和其他生产性事业提供资金的资本主义，以及更多使他们变得富有和强大的突破性成果。荷兰人创建了世界上第一个巨型公司 —— 荷兰东印度公司，该公司约占世界贸易的三分之一。 3 荷兰人对新思想、新人物和新技术的开放态度帮助他们迅速崛起。
  • To support trade the Dutch government increased military investments, which allowed the country to control still more trade by holding off the British in a number of military conflicts.
  • 为了支持贸易，荷兰政府增加了军事投资，这使得该国能够通过在一些军事冲突中抵制英国人而控制更多的贸易。
  • The Dutch also created the world’s first reserve currency other than gold and silver, the Dutch guilder, supported by an innovative banking and currency system put into place via the establishment of the Bank of Amsterdam. 4
  • 荷兰人还创造了世界上第一个除黄金和白银之外的储备货币 —— 荷兰盾，并通过建立阿姆斯特丹银行来支持一个创新的银行和货币体系。 4

As a result of these classic and sound fundamental steps, the Dutch became rich—income per capita in the Netherlands rose to over twice that of most other European powers. The Dutch continued to invest heavily in education and infrastructure to build on their successes. Dutch literacy rates reached twice the world average. They continued to develop their capital markets and Amsterdam became the world’s most important financial center. The Dutch did all of this with a population of only 1–2 million people.

由于这些经典和健全的基本步骤，荷兰人变得富有 —— 荷兰的人均收入上升到大多数其他欧洲国家的两倍以上。荷兰人继续大量投资于教育和基础设施，以巩固他们的成功。荷兰人的识字率达到了世界平均水平的两倍。他们继续发展其资本市场，阿姆斯特丹成为世界上最重要的金融中心。荷兰人在只有 1-2 百万人口的情况下做到了这一切。

The following charts provide some perspective on the unique nature of Dutch education, innovation, and trade in the 1600s and the impact these forces had on Dutch incomes, all of which we will explore later in this chapter.

以下图表提供了一些关于 16 世纪荷兰教育、创新和贸易的独特性质以及这些力量对荷兰收入的影响的观点，我们将在本章后面探讨所有这些问题。

In short, the Dutch were superbly educated people who were very hardworking and inventive— in fact, they came up with about a quarter of all major inventions in the world when they were at their peak, a spike that began shortly before Dutch independence from Spain.

简而言之，荷兰人是受过良好教育的人，他们非常勤奋和富有创造力 —— 事实上，当他们处于鼎盛时期时，他们提出了世界上所有主要发明的四分之一，这一高峰始于荷兰从西班牙独立前不久。

To reiterate, the two most important inventions they came up with were 1) uniquely effective sailing ships that could take them all around the world, which, with the military skills they acquired from the fighting they did in Europe, allowed them to collect great riches, and 2) the capitalism that fueled these endeavors.

重申一下，他们想出的两个最重要的发明是：1）独特有效的帆船，可以把他们带到世界各地，加上他们在欧洲的战斗中获得的军事技能，使他们能够收集大量财富；2）为这些努力提供动力的资本主义。

The Capital Markets Cycle of the Dutch

荷兰的资本市场周期

The Dutch invented capitalism as we know it. This was great for the Dutch and great for the world, but like most great inventions, it brought with it some potentially deadly consequences. While production, trade, and private ownership had existed before, the ability of large numbers of people to collectively buy ownership in money-making endeavors through public equity markets did not exist. The Dutch created that when they invented the world’s first publicly listed company (the Dutch East India Company) and the first stock exchange in 1602.

荷兰人发明了我们所知的资本主义。这对荷兰人来说是伟大的，对世界来说也是伟大的，但像大多数伟大的发明一样，它也带来了一些潜在的致命后果。虽然生产、贸易和私人所有权以前就存在，但大量的人通过公共股权市场集体购买赚钱事业的所有权的能力并不存在。荷兰人在 1602 年发明了世界上第一家公开上市的公司（荷兰东印度公司）和第一家证券交易所，创造了这一现象。

Like most inventions, these capital market developments arose out of necessity and self-interest. The voyages across the world in search of new trade routes were risky ventures, so it made sense for merchants to sell some of the risk associated with the voyage to others in exchange for a share of the future profits. At the time the Dutch introduced equity shares in their voyages in the mid-1500s, it was revolutionary. Until 1600, these shares were held by only a small number of merchants, largely lacked transparency, and were illiquid, so their attractiveness to outside investors was limited.

像大多数发明一样，这些资本市场的发展也是出于需要和自身利益的考虑。为寻找新的贸易路线而在世界各地进行的航行是有风险的，因此，商人将与航行有关的一些风险出售给他人以换取未来的利润份额是有意义的。在 15 世纪中期，荷兰人在他们的航行中引入了股权，这是一种革命性的做法。在 1600 年之前，这些股份只由少数商人持有，基本上缺乏透明度，而且流动性不强，所以对外部投资者的吸引力有限。

The formation of the Amsterdam Stock Exchange in August 1602 and the listing of the Dutch East India Company spread share ownership much wider (more than one in 50 Dutch adults owned shares), and the exchange’s clear rules about ownership and transfer of shares made the market much more transparent. The Dutch East India Company was an equally revolutionary invention. The world’s first transnational corporation, it had many of the features you see in companies today —shareholders, a corporate logo, a board of directors, etc. Capital markets enabled investors to save, merchants to raise funds, and everyone to have a liquid market in which transfers of capital could happen easily and efficiently, fueling a new era of wealth accumulation. At their peak in the early 1700s, Dutch East India Company dividends accounted for nearly $1 out of every $100 of total Dutch GDP.

1602 年 8 月阿姆斯特丹证券交易所的成立和荷兰东印度公司的上市，使股票所有权得到了更广泛的传播（每 50 个荷兰成年人中就有一个以上拥有股票），而交易所关于股票所有权和转让的明确规则使市场更加透明。荷兰东印度公司也是一项革命性的发明。它是世界上第一个跨国公司，具有今天你在公司中看到的许多特征 —— 股东、公司标志、董事会等。资本市场使投资者能够储蓄，商人能够筹集资金，每个人都有一个流动的市场，资本的转移可以很容易和有效地发生，推动了财富积累的新时代。在 17 世纪初的高峰期，荷兰东印度公司的红利占荷兰 GDP 总额每 100 美元中的近 1 美元。

Importantly, the Dutch outcompeted the Spanish and the Portuguese, which led them to win the main prize—a higher share of the trading between Europe and Asia, particularly China and Indonesia, which was very profitable.

重要的是，荷兰人超越了西班牙人和葡萄牙人，这使他们赢得了主要奖项 —— 在欧洲和亚洲，特别是中国和印度尼西亚之间的贸易中获得了更高的份额，这是非常有利的。

In addition to creating an equity market, the Dutch developed an innovative banking system, which grew rapidly and began to finance international trade for Dutch and non-Dutch merchants. Prior to the Dutch banking innovations, the international currency situation was a mess. In the late 1500s, around 800 different foreign and domestic coins circulated in the Netherlands, many of which were debased (i.e., had a lowered content of precious metal in the coins) and difficult to distinguish from counterfeits. This created uncertainty over the value of money, which made international trade slower and more expensive.

除了创建股权市场外，荷兰人还开发了一个创新的银行系统，该系统发展迅速，并开始为荷兰和非荷兰商人的国际贸易提供资金。在荷兰的银行创新之前，国际货币状况是一团糟。在 15 世纪末，大约有 800 种不同的外国和国内硬币在荷兰流通，其中许多是贬值的（即硬币中的贵金属含量降低），难以与假币区分。这造成了货币价值的不确定性，使国际贸易变得更加缓慢和昂贵。

In 1609, the Bank of Amsterdam was established as an exchange bank to protect commercial creditors from unreliable commodity money in general circulation. The Bank of Amsterdam undertook activities that would generate monetary stability and put the Netherlands’ coinage, the bank’s letters of credit, and the Dutch financial system at the center of global finance. Notably, this bank guilder, though backed by hard currency, was essentially Type 2 money. That set up the guilder as a true reserve currency, the first of its kind.

1609 年，阿姆斯特丹银行作为一家外汇银行成立，以保护商业债权人免受一般流通中不可靠的商品货币的影响。阿姆斯特丹银行开展的活动将产生货币稳定性，并将荷兰的硬币、银行的信用证和荷兰的金融体系置于全球金融的中心。值得注意的是，这种银行盾，虽然有硬通货支持，但基本上是第二类货币。这使得荷兰盾成为一种真正的储备货币，这是第一种储备货币。

As a result of this system, the guilder remained effective as both a medium of exchange and a storehold of wealth. Bank of Amsterdam bills of exchange improved their status as a reserve currency. Baltic and Russian trade relied solely on guilders and Bank of Amsterdam bills of exchange for pricing and contract settlement. 5

由于这一制度，荷兰盾作为一种交换媒介和财富储备仍然有效。阿姆斯特丹银行的汇票提高了其作为储备货币的地位。波罗的海和俄罗斯的贸易完全依靠荷兰盾和阿姆斯特丹银行的汇票进行定价和合同结算。 5

The New World Order: The Thirty Years’ War and the Peace of Westphalia

世界新秩序。三十年战争与威斯特伐利亚和平

Then came the Thirty Years’ War (1618–48). While the Dutch played a relatively minor role in the Europe-wide conflict, it is worth covering this war in some detail given its importance to the internal and external orders of Europe more broadly. It is also a classic case of how internal and external orders work together.

然后是三十年战争（1618-48）。虽然荷兰人在全欧洲的冲突中扮演的角色相对较小，但鉴于这场战争对欧洲内部和外部秩序更广泛的重要性，还是值得详细介绍一下。这也是内部和外部秩序如何协同工作的一个典型案例。

All the classic balance of power dynamics came into play. In this case, the Thirty Years’ War was a classic fight over wealth and power, just a lot longer one. On one side was the Catholic emperor of Habsburg Austria, who was allied with the German Catholic territories (most prominently Bavaria), as well as with Spain and the Papal States. On the other side were the German Protestant nobles, allied at different points in time with Denmark, the Netherlands, Sweden, and France. The fighting was about money, religion (Protestants versus Catholics), and geopolitics. The alliances were pretty complex. For example, the French monarchy—despite being Catholic and having Cardinal Richelieu6 driving policy—was allied (first secretly, then openly) with both Lutheran Sweden and largely Calvinist Netherlands. That is because money and geopolitics mattered more than religious ideologies.

所有经典的权力平衡动态都发挥了作用。在这种情况下，三十年战争是一场典型的财富和权力之争，只是时间长了很多。一方是哈布斯堡奥地利的天主教皇帝，他与德国天主教领土（最突出的是巴伐利亚）以及西班牙和教皇国结盟。另一方是德国新教贵族，在不同时期与丹麦、荷兰、瑞典和法国结盟。战斗是关于金钱、宗教（新教徒对天主教）和地缘政治的。这些联盟是相当复杂的。例如，法国君主国 —— 尽管是天主教徒，并由黎塞留枢机主教主导政策 —— 是盟国（首先是法国）。6政策，但却与路德教的瑞典和主要是加尔文教的荷兰结盟（先是秘密结盟，然后公开结盟）。这是因为金钱和地缘政治比宗教意识形态更重要。

The Habsburgs lost the war. That left them in a meaningfully weakened position. The treaty that established the new international order, the Peace of Westphalia, expanded the autonomy of the individual princes of the Holy Roman Empire, further eroding the limited authority of the Austrian emperor over the other states. More importantly, the deal that was cut at Westphalia invented countries as we know them, which is to say it allowed sovereignty of the state with the ability to make choices within its geographic borders (e.g., their religions, their languages, and all their rules) and instituted respect for those boundaries so that no longer would borderless, free-flowing power grabs occur (without, of course, the understanding that you’d be starting a major war). The emergence of the concept of states led to nationalism and the pursuit of national interests, which reshaped the concept of the balance of power between rival states. It also made the religious authorities much less powerful.

哈布斯堡王朝在战争中失败了。这使他们处于一个有意义的被削弱的地位。建立新的国际秩序的条约，即《威斯特伐利亚和约》，扩大了神圣罗马帝国各个王子的自主权，进一步削弱了奥地利皇帝对其他国家的有限权力。更重要的是，在威斯特伐利亚达成的协议发明了我们所知道的国家，也就是说，它允许国家拥有主权，有能力在其地理边界内做出选择（例如，他们的宗教、语言和所有的规则），并制定了对这些边界的尊重，以便不再发生无边界、自由流动的权力掠夺（当然，没有理解到你会引发一场重大战争）。国家概念的出现导致了民族主义和对国家利益的追求，这重塑了敌对国家之间权力平衡的概念。这也使得宗教当局的权力大大降低。

The Peace of Westphalia reflected what I call the “exhaustion of war,” which contributed to a long period of peace and prosperity that followed. Like all big wars, the Thirty Years’ War produced devastating losses of life, property, and wealth. One quarter of the population of Europe died from combat, disease, or starvation. Because wars are so much more terrible than even those who are eager for them can imagine, they lead to treaties that redefine the order and are followed by periods of peace, until the next big war happens.

威斯特伐利亚和约反映了我所说的 “战争的衰竭”，它促成了随后的长期和平与繁荣。像所有大型战争一样，三十年战争在生命、财产和财富方面造成了毁灭性的损失。欧洲四分之一的人口死于战斗、疾病或饥饿。因为战争的可怕程度甚至超过了那些渴望战争的人的想象，所以战争导致了重新定义秩序的条约，之后是和平时期，直到下一场大战争发生。

The Dutch benefited greatly from the new balance of power and period of relative stability ; probably most importantly, it protected them from the threat of Habsburg domination.

荷兰人从新的权力平衡和相对稳定的时期中受益匪浅；可能最重要的是，它保护他们免受哈布斯堡统治的威胁。

It is also the case that●wars are devastating financially; that is true for the winners and much more so for the losers. For example, France, though a “winner” and only indirectly involved for much of the war, experienced such bad financial problems and instability as a result that it was faced with widespread rebellions. The losing Habsburg Empire was even more devastated. Relative to the French and Spanish, the Dutch were less financially hurt. They benefited from the peace that fostered the Dutch Golden Age. The Dutch also benefited from the military developments that occurred in the war because, when coupled with the shipping capabilities of the Dutch East India Company, this strong shipping and military combination expanded Dutch power around the world.

事实也是如此，●战争在经济上是毁灭性的；对胜利者是如此，对失败者更是如此。例如，法国虽然是 “胜利者”，而且在战争的大部分时间里只是间接参与，但却因此经历了如此糟糕的财政问题和不稳定，以至于它面临着广泛的叛乱。失败的哈布斯堡帝国甚至受到了更大的破坏。相对于法国和西班牙，荷兰人在经济上受到的伤害较小。他们从促进荷兰黄金时代的和平中受益。荷兰人还从战争中发生的军事发展中受益，因为当与荷兰东印度公司的航运能力相结合时，这种强大的航运和军事组合扩大了荷兰在全世界的力量。

THE TOP

顶层

The Dutch Golden Age led the Dutch to shift their attentions to “living the good life” in a way that weakened their finances. Other powers rose too and began to challenge them. The arrival of capitalism, combined with the new approaches of the Enlightenment, led to an economic transformation called the Industrial Revolution, which was centered in Britain. The Dutch, who had been the unparalleled leaders in innovation, trade, and wealth in the 1600s, failed to keep up. Eventually the cost of maintaining a declining and overextended empire became unsustainable.

荷兰的黄金时代使荷兰人将注意力转移到 “美好生活” 上，而这种方式削弱了他们的财政。其他大国也纷纷崛起，开始挑战他们。资本主义的到来，加上启蒙运动的新方法，导致了一场以英国为中心的经济转型，即工业革命。在 16 世纪，荷兰人在创新、贸易和财富方面一直是无与伦比的领导者，但他们没能跟上。最终，维持一个衰落和过度扩张的帝国的成本变得不可持续。

This chart shows a number of key steps.

这个图表显示了一些关键步骤。

At the top, the Dutch saw a reversal of many of the classic ingredients we discussed earlier:

在顶部，荷兰人看到了我们之前讨论的许多经典成分的逆转。

  • The Dutch educational and technological edge eroded.
  • 荷兰的教育和技术优势受到侵蚀。
  • The Dutch became uncompetitive in general and via the decline of the Dutch East India Company.
  • 荷兰人在总体上和通过荷兰东印度公司的衰落变得没有竞争力。
  • In the 1700s, the Industrial Revolution led the British to overtake the Dutch as the preeminent economic and financial power in Europe.
  • 17 世纪，工业革命使英国超越荷兰，成为欧洲卓越的经济和金融大国。
  • Slower economic growth relative to other powers made it more difficult to pay for and maintain its vast empire (especially one controlled by such a small nation). Increasing military conflicts (in attempts to protect their vast wealth around the world) left the Dutch overextended and overindebted.
  • 相对于其他大国来说，经济增长较慢，使其更难支付和维持其庞大的帝国（尤其是由这样一个小国控制的帝国）。越来越多的军事冲突（试图保护他们在世界各地的巨大财富）使荷兰人过度扩张，负债累累。
  • This all set the stage for the decline in the guilder’s reserve currency status, which ultimately deteriorated after the Dutch lost a war (and with it, important assets) to the British.
  • 这一切都为荷兰盾储备货币地位的下降创造了条件，在荷兰输给英国一场战争（以及随之而来的重要资产）后，荷兰盾的地位最终恶化。
  • With the Dutch Empire weakened, its financial center eroded, especially after a series of debt crises and a run on the central bank and currency.
  • 随着荷兰帝国的衰弱，其金融中心受到侵蚀，特别是在一系列债务危机和中央银行和货币的挤兑之后。

Even though the Peace of Westphalia brought relative peace and stability to Europe, the Dutch were still engaged in a number of conflicts throughout their time as an empire, as opponents saw their weaknesses and attacked, especially via naval wars fought over trade. Here is a brief summary of the wars the Dutch fought to build and then to hold on to its empire:

尽管威斯特伐利亚和约给欧洲带来了相对的和平与稳定，但在整个帝国时期，荷兰人仍然参与了许多冲突，因为对手看到了他们的弱点并进行了攻击，特别是通过为贸易而打的海战。以下是荷兰为建立和保持其帝国而进行的战争的简要总结。

  • Eighty Years’ War (1566–1648) : This was the revolt by Protestant Netherlands against Catholic Spain. The Dutch first declared independence in 1581, but their full independence was not realized until the Peace of Westphalia (1648) ended both the Thirty Years’ War and the Eighty Years’ War.
  • 八十年战争（1566-1648）：这是新教荷兰对天主教西班牙的反抗。荷兰于 1581 年首次宣布独立，但直到《威斯特伐利亚和约》（1648 年）结束了三十年战争和八十年战争，他们才实现了全面独立。
  • The First Anglo-Dutch War (1652–54) : This was a trade war that began when the English Parliament passed the Navigation Act of 1651, mandating that all goods from its American colonies be carried by English ships. The war was largely a stalemate and failed to resolve the trade rivalry between the nations.
  • 第一次英荷战争（1652-54）：这是一场贸易战争，始于英国议会通过的 1651 年《航海法》，规定所有来自其美洲殖民地的货物必须由英国船只运输。这场战争在很大程度上是一场僵局，未能解决国家之间的贸易竞争。
  • The Dano-Swedish War (1657–60) : This began when Sweden declared war on Denmark, a Dutch ally, threatening the highly profitable Baltic trade routes. The Dutch defeated the Swedish.
  • 达诺·瑞典战争（1657-60）：战争开始时，瑞典向荷兰的盟友丹麦宣战，威胁到利润极高的波罗的海贸易路线。荷兰人击败了瑞典人。
  • The Second Anglo-Dutch War (1665–67) : England and the Netherlands fought over another trade dispute, which ended with a Dutch victory.
  • 第二次英荷战争（1665-67）：英格兰和荷兰因另一场贸易争端而发生争斗，最终以荷兰的胜利而告终。
  • The Franco-Dutch War (1672–78) and the Third Anglo-Dutch War (1672–74) : These were also fights over trade. The Dutch foiled French plans to conquer the Netherlands and forced them to reduce some of their tariffs, but at a tremendous cost.
  • 法荷战争（1672-78）和第三次英荷战争（1672-74）：这些也是为贸易而战。荷兰人挫败了法国人征服荷兰的计划，迫使他们降低一些关税，但也付出了巨大的代价。
  • The Fourth Anglo-Dutch War (1780–84) : The British began the war in retaliation for Dutch support of the colonies in the American Revolution. It ended in a significant defeat for the Dutch, ushering in the end of the guilder as a reserve currency.
  • 第四次英荷战争（1780-84）：英国开始了这场战争，以报复荷兰在美国革命中对殖民地的支持。这场战争以荷兰人的重大失败而告终，迎来了荷兰盾作为储备货币的终结。

Ironically, it was a military victory, one that began nearly a century of peace, that led power to shift away from the Netherlands. In 1688, William III of Orange married Mary II, who was the daughter of the unpopular king of England, and successfully invaded England and took power. This was known as the Glorious Revolution and created a new internal order for Great Britain. While it was undoubtedly good for the Dutch in the short run to have William III on the British throne, the second-order consequences of economic integration and military cooperation played a major role in the decline of Dutch economic power and the guilder over the next century.

具有讽刺意味的是，正是一场军事胜利，一场开始了近一个世纪的和平，导致权力从荷兰转移。1688 年，奥兰治的威廉三世与不受欢迎的英国国王的女儿玛丽二世结婚，并成功入侵英国，夺取了政权。这被称为 “光荣革命”，为英国创造了新的内部秩序。虽然从短期来看，威廉三世登上英国王位对荷兰人无疑是件好事，但经济一体化和军事合作的二阶后果在接下来的一个世纪里对荷兰经济实力和盾牌的衰落起了重要作用。

After 1688, as Great Britain became more competitive, Dutch merchants shifted their operations to London, hastening its rise as an international center of finance. The alliance also gave English merchants access to Dutch trade. William III moved to England instead of focusing his attention on ruling the Netherlands. When he died heirless in 1702, the direct connection between the two nations was broken, and the various Dutch provinces that had been unified under him began to splinter. While England and the Netherlands continued to have military partnerships against the French during most of the 80-plus years leading up to the Fourth Anglo-Dutch War, by the mid-1700s they were beginning to bump into each other in many of the same markets.

1688 年后，随着英国的竞争力增强，荷兰商人将他们的业务转移到伦敦，加速了伦敦作为国际金融中心的崛起。该联盟还使英国商人有机会进入荷兰贸易。威廉三世搬到了英国，而不是把注意力放在统治荷兰上。当他在 1702 年去世时，没有继承人，两国之间的直接联系被打破，在他手下统一的各个荷兰省份开始分裂。虽然在第四次英荷战争之前的 80 多年里，英格兰和荷兰继续保持着对抗法国人的军事合作关系，但到了 17 世纪中期，他们开始在许多相同的市场上相互碰撞。

By the mid-18th century, the Dutch Empire was no longer the world’s leading empire. Britain especially had learned from Dutch innovations and made their own investments in education to strengthen their people’s capabilities. These abilities, coupled with the use of capitalism, led to the advancements that made up the Industrial Revolution, which brought about constant improvements on existing concepts to make production more efficient, such as standardizing inputs and moving production from individual artisans to factories. It also led to transformative new inventions. This allowed the British to become more productive, capture more trade, and build military might.

到 18 世纪中叶，荷兰帝国已不再是世界上最主要的帝国。特别是英国从荷兰的创新中学习，并在教育方面进行了自己的投资，以加强其人民的能力。这些能力，加上资本主义的使用，导致了构成工业革命的进步，它带来了对现有概念的不断改进，使生产更有效率，如标准化的投入和将生产从个体工匠转移到工厂。它还导致了变革性的新发明。这使英国人能够提高生产力，获得更多的贸易，并建立军事力量。

Additionally, and as is classic, as the Dutch became extremely wealthy, they became less competitive —for example, their wages were generally higher than those in other parts of Europe. The Dutch East India Company lost its competitive edge as well. For example, it was ineffective in trading popular new products like tea. Dutch economic growth slowed relative to other powers, which made it more difficult for the Dutch to pay for and maintain their vast empire. Increasing military conflicts to protect their vast wealth left them overextended.

此外，正如经典的那样，随着荷兰人变得极其富有，他们的竞争力也在下降 —— 例如，他们的工资普遍高于欧洲其他地区的水平。荷兰东印度公司也失去了其竞争优势。例如，它在茶叶等流行的新产品的贸易中没有效果。相对于其他大国，荷兰的经济增长放缓，这使得荷兰人更难支付和维持其庞大的帝国。为保护其庞大的财富而不断增加的军事冲突使他们过度扩张。

Thus, from around 1725 through around 1800 the financial decline unfolded in the classic ways. These charts do a good job of conveying both the ascent and the decline of the Bank of Amsterdam.

因此，从 1725 年左右到 1800 年左右，金融衰退以经典方式展开。这些图表很好地传达了阿姆斯特丹银行的上升和下降过程。

As is classic, the reserve currency status of the guilder remained strong even as the Netherlands’ other powers began to decline. Because bills of exchange were the dominant vehicle for international trade credit, all merchants wishing to trade with the Dutch were forced to open an account at the Bank of Amsterdam, which led to around 40 percent of global trade being settled in Amsterdam using bank guilders. The importance of the Dutch in trade and financial transactions, the Bank of Amsterdam’s policies that made the guilder very effective as both a medium of exchange and a storehold of wealth, and the fact that Dutch commercial entities and banks insisted on its usage all cemented the guilder’s place as the first global reserve currency.7 This gave the Dutch the “extraordinary privilege” of being able to get into a lot of debt.

如同典型的情况一样，即使荷兰的其他势力开始衰落，荷兰盾的储备货币地位仍然很强。由于汇票是国际贸易信贷的主要工具，所有希望与荷兰人进行贸易的商人都被迫在阿姆斯特丹银行开立账户，这导致约 40% 的全球贸易是在阿姆斯特丹使用银行盾结算。荷兰人在贸易和金融交易中的重要性，阿姆斯特丹银行的政策使荷兰盾作为一种交换媒介和财富储备非常有效，以及荷兰商业实体和银行坚持使用荷兰盾的事实，都巩固了荷兰盾作为第一个全球储备货币的地位。7这给了荷兰人 “非同寻常的特权”，使他们能够承担大量的债务。

THE DECLINE

衰落

Around 1750 the British (and the French) became stronger than the Dutch, both because their own power had grown and because the Dutch had become weaker. As is classic, the Dutch a) became more indebted, b) experienced a lot of internal fighting over wealth, 8 and c) weakened militarily. All this made them vulnerable to decline and attack.

1750 年左右，英国人（和法国人）变得比荷兰人更强大，这是因为他们自己的力量增长了，也因为荷兰人变得更弱。典型的情况是，荷兰人 a）变得更加负债累累，b）经历了大量的财富内斗。 8 和 c）军事上的削弱。所有这些都使他们容易受到衰退和攻击。

As earnings from abroad fell, wealthy Dutch savers moved their cash into British investments, which were more attractive due to their strong growth and higher yields.9 Despite this, the guilder remained widely used as a global reserve currency. As explained earlier, reserve currency status classically lags the decline of other key drivers of the rise and fall of empires. Then, as is typical, a rising great power challenged the existing great power in a war.

由于来自国外的收入下降，富有的荷兰储蓄者将他们的现金转移到英国的投资中，由于英国的强劲增长和较高的收益率，英国的投资更具吸引力。9尽管如此，荷兰盾仍然作为全球储备货币被广泛使用。正如前面解释的那样，储备货币的地位通常滞后于帝国兴衰的其他关键驱动因素的下降。然后，像典型的那样，一个崛起的大国在战争中挑战现有的大国。

Starting in the 1770s, the English began to interfere with Dutch shipping, escalating the conflict after the Dutch traded arms with the colonies during the American Revolution. In retaliation, the English delivered a massive blow to the Dutch Navy in the Caribbean in 1781, taking over Dutch territories there and in the East Indies as well. Having lost half its ships and access to its key trade routes, the Dutch East India Company had to borrow heavily from the Bank of Amsterdam to stay alive. Rival powers took the Dutch defeat as an opportunity to grab still more of the Dutch shipping business. British blockades in the Netherlands and in the East Indies caused a liquidity crisis. The financial consequences of these events can be seen in the following charts.

从 1770 年代开始，英国人开始干涉荷兰航运，在美国革命期间荷兰与殖民地进行武器交易后，冲突升级。作为报复，英国人于 1781 年在加勒比海地区对荷兰海军进行了大规模打击，占领了荷兰在那里和东印度群岛的领土。荷兰东印度公司失去了一半的船只和关键的贸易路线，不得不向阿姆斯特丹银行大量借款以维持生存。敌对势力将荷兰的失败作为一个机会，以抢夺更多的荷兰航运业务。英国在荷兰和东印度群岛的封锁造成了流动性危机。这些事件的金融后果可以从以下图表中看出。

10

Financial losses and large debts led to the classic move by the central bank to print more money. As the Bank of Amsterdam printed more and more paper money to provide loans to the Dutch East India Company, it soon became clear that there would not be enough gold and silver to cover all the paper claims on it. That led to the classic “run on the bank” dynamic, in which investors exchanged their paper money for precious metals. With the bank’s store of precious metals exhausted, the supply of guilders soared, even as demand for them fell, as shown in the following chart.
